template.name: AWS_Workload Discovery
template.desc: Workload Discovery on AWS (formerly called AWS Perspective) is a tool to visualize AWS Cloud workloads. Use this AWS Solution to build, customize, and share detailed architecture diagrams of your workloads based on live data from AWS. The solution maintains an inventory of the AWS resources across your accounts and AWS Regions, mapping relationships between them, and displaying them in a web user interface (UI). The solution also comes with a cost query builder that lets you locate AWS resources and services that may have incurred a cost. The estimated cost data is automatically calculated for the time period specified and displays on your architecture diagrams. You can generate a cost report for your architecture diagrams that contains an overview of the estimated cost and export them as CSV. The image to the right is a sample architecture diagram generated by the solution.

component.desc: Amazon Athena, an interactive query service to analyze data in S3 using SQL.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

countermeasure.name: Anonymize sensitive data in datasets
countermeasure.desc:
Anonymizing data is a crucial step in protecting sensitive information and minimizing the risk of exposing personal data within datasets analyzed by Amazon Athena. By implementing data anonymization, you ensure that personal data is obscured or de-identified, reducing the potential for unauthorized access and data breaches.

To effectively anonymize data in Amazon Athena, follow these guidelines:

  1. Understand Data Sensitivity and Compliance Requirements: Identify the types of sensitive data within your datasets and understand the compliance requirements that apply to your organization. This will help you determine the appropriate level of anonymization needed.
  2. Leverage AWS Lake Formation for Data Governance: Utilize AWS Lake Formation to manage and enforce fine-grained access controls on your datasets. Lake Formation allows you to create and enforce policies that help protect sensitive data. More details can be found in the Anonymize and manage data in your data lake with Amazon Athena and AWS Lake Formation blog post.
  3. Use Built-in Anonymization Functions: Amazon Athena provides built-in functions to help with data anonymization, such as masking, tokenization, and encryption. For instance, you can use SQL expressions to replace certain data fields with anonymized values. Refer to the AWS Athena Security Documentation to learn more about the available functions and how to use them securely.
  4. Implement Field-Level Encryption: Use field-level encryption to encrypt sensitive fields within your datasets. This ensures that even if unauthorized access occurs, the sensitive data remains protected. AWS KMS (Key Management Service) can be used to manage cryptographic keys securely.
  5. Regularly Audit and Monitor Data Access: Conduct regular audits and monitor access to your data. AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config can help you track and log access to your Amazon Athena queries and underlying data stores, providing visibility into user actions and potential security issues.

By following these steps and leveraging the capabilities of Amazon Athena and AWS Lake Formation, you can effectively anonymize your data, thereby enhancing the security and privacy of the information analyzed within your data lake.

For further reference, consult the official Amazon Athena Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption of Athena table data
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure data stored in Amazon S3 buckets used by AWS Athena is protected from unauthorized access, configuring encryption at rest is paramount. This involves enabling server-side encryption (SSE) for the relevant S3 buckets. Follow these steps to implement this control:

  1. Navigate to the S3 Management Console in your AWS account.
  2. Select the bucket where Athena stores its data.
  3. Go to the "Properties" tab of the selected bucket.
  4. Locate the "Default encryption" section and click on "Edit."
  5. Choose your preferred encryption method:
    • SSE-S3: Server-Side Encryption with Amazon S3-Managed Keys.
    • SSE-KMS: Server-Side Encryption with AWS Key Management Service (KMS) Keys.
    • SSE-C: Server-Side Encryption with Customer-Provided Keys.
  6. Click "Save changes" to enable or update the encryption settings.

Enabling server-side encryption helps you comply with security standards and protects your sensitive data from unauthorized access. For more detailed instructions, refer to the official AWS documentation on encrypting data in Athena and the overarching security guidelines for Amazon S3 buckets available here.

countermeasure.name: Implement AWS Lake Formation to enforce strict access controls
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing and enforcing detailed access control policies using AWS Lake Formation can significantly enhance the security posture of your data lake environment. AWS Lake Formation provides fine-grained access controls over data stored in Amazon S3, enabling you to restrict access to datasets by granting permissions at the database, table, column, or row level. This ensures only authorized users can access specific datasets, thereby minimizing the risk of unauthorized data access.

To begin, ensure that AWS Lake Formation is set up and integrated with your existing AWS Athena environment. Follow these steps:

  1. Configure AWS Lake Formation: First, navigate to the AWS Lake Formation console. Here, register your Amazon S3 data lake storage resources by specifying the Amazon S3 locations where your data resides. Refer to the AWS Lake Formation Getting Started Guide for detailed instructions.
  2. Define Access Control Policies: Use Lake Formation permissions to grant database, table, and column-level access to specific IAM users or roles. For instance, a policy might restrict access to a table containing sensitive information such as PII (Personally Identifiable Information) to only specific roles. Detailed instructions on defining these policies can be found in the AWS Lake Formation Data Access Control documentation.
  3. Integrate with AWS Athena: Ensure that your AWS Athena queries are compliant with the access controls set in Lake Formation. When users run queries in Athena, Lake Formation credentials automatically enforce the defined permissions, thus controlling access to the datasets. Review the AWS Athena and Lake Formation Integration Guide for implementation details.
  4. Monitor and Audit Access: Regularly monitor and audit access to your datasets using AWS CloudTrail and AWS Lake Formation's audit capabilities. This helps in tracking user activities and ensuring compliance with your organization's security policies. For more details, refer to the Athena CloudTrail Logs documentation and the Lake Formation Auditing documentation.

By leveraging AWS Lake Formation to implement and enforce detailed access control policies, you effectively reduce the risk of unauthorized data access in your Amazon Athena queries, thereby strengthening your overall data security strategy.

countermeasure.name: Secure query result sets
countermeasure.desc:
Storing Query Results in Encrypted S3 Buckets and Restricting Access Using IAM and S3 Bucket Policies

A key measure to secure your AWS Athena query results involves storing them in encrypted Amazon S3 buckets and ensuring that access to these buckets is strictly controlled using IAM and S3 bucket policies. Follow the steps below to implement this control effectively:

Step 1: Create an Encrypted S3 Bucket

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console.
  2. Navigate to the Amazon S3 service.
  3. Create a new S3 bucket, or select an existing one where you want to store the query results.
  4. Ensure that server-side encryption (SSE) is enabled for the bucket. You can use either SSE-S3 or SSE-KMS.

Step 2: Set Up IAM Policies

IAM policies are essential to control which users and roles have permissions to access the S3 bucket and perform actions on it. Follow these steps:

  1. Navigate to the IAM service in the AWS Management Console.
  2. Define a policy that grants necessary permissions to access the specified S3 bucket. You can utilize managed polices or create a custom policy. An example policy could be:

{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Action": "s3:*",
            "Resource": ["arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name", "arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name/*"]
        }
    ]
}

Attach this policy to the respective IAM roles that need access.

Step 3: Configure S3 Bucket Policies

S3 bucket policies can be used to enforce security controls on a specific bucket. Steps to configure S3 bucket policies:

  1. Select the S3 bucket created in step 1.
  2. Go to the 'Permissions' tab.
  3. Add a bucket policy that restricts access based on IAM roles, specific IP ranges, or conditions, ensuring fine-grained control over who accesses your bucket. A sample policy might look like this:

{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Principal": {"AWS": "arn:aws:iam::account-id:role/RoleName"},
            "Action": "s3:GetObject",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::your-bucket-name/*",
            "Condition": {
                "IpAddress": {"aws:SourceIp": "your-ip-range"}
            }
        }
    ]
}

By following these procedures, you ensure that your Athena query results are stored securely and that access to these results is tightly controlled. For more detailed information, please refer to the AWS Athena Security Documentation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Use CalledVia context keys
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS Athena service, it is crucial to limit requests to AWS Athena by configuring policies to include the aws:CalledVia global condition context key. This ensures requests are made only from authorized services.

Begin by identifying the services that are authorized to make requests to AWS Athena. These could be AWS Lambda functions, AWS Glue, or other AWS services in your environment.

Next, modify the IAM policies associated with your Athena-related roles to include the aws:CalledVia condition. This condition context key allows you to specify the services that are permitted to invoke Athena actions.

Heres a step-by-step guide to implement this:

  1. Identify the IAM roles and policies that need to be updated.
  2. Open the IAM Management Console.
  3. Navigate to the relevant policy you wish to update.
  4. Edit the policy to include the Condition block with the aws:CalledVia context key. 
    
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": {
    "Effect": "Allow",
    "Action": "athena:*",
    "Resource": "*",
    "Condition": {
      "StringEquals": {
        "aws:CalledVia": [
          "lambda.amazonaws.com",
          "glue.amazonaws.com"
        ]
      }
    }
  }
}
  5. Apply and save the updated policy.

By including the aws:CalledVia condition context key, you significantly reduce the surface area for unauthorized access to Athena. This control ensures that only requests from specified AWS services, such as Lambda or Glue, are allowed to interact with Athena.

For further details and guidance, please refer to the official AWS Athena security documentation.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access through intermediary services
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized or intermediary services interacting with AWS Athena can lead to data leaks or malicious activities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors, insiders, or unauthorized third-party services exploiting misconfigurations or security gaps.
Impacts
Exposure of sensitive data, financial loss, compliance violations, and potential damage to the organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to AWS Athena credentials through a compromised third-party service and executes queries to exfiltrate sensitive information. Alternatively, an insider uses intermediary services to route unauthorized requests, causing data exposure or unauthorized data modification.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without strict access controls, unauthorized users might gain access to sensitive data, leading to potential data theft or misuse.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, external hackers exploiting loose access permissions, and users accidentally sharing access credentials.
Impacts
Loss of sensitive data, financial repercussions, damage to reputation, and potential legal consequences.
Example Attack Scenarios
A malicious insider with knowledge of the system gains unauthorized access to financial records. An external hacker exploits a misconfigured IAM policy to access proprietary business information. A user accidentally shares their access credentials with a phishing attacker, compromising customer data.

threat.name: Unencrypted table data
threat.desc:
General threat description
If data within Athena tables is not encrypted, it may be accessed by unauthorized parties, leading to potential data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, malicious insiders, or attackers exploiting misconfigurations or vulnerabilities in the AWS environment.
Impacts
Unauthorized data access, potential data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and damage to organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an AWS account and finds unencrypted Athena tables containing sensitive data, which they can exfiltrate. A malicious insider with access to Athena tables abuses their permissions to access and share sensitive information without detection.

threat.name: Improper result set access
threat.desc:
General threat description
If result sets of Athena queries are not properly secured, they could be accessed by unauthorized users.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized personnel gaining access to improperly secured Athena query result sets through misconfigured access permissions.
Impacts
Data breaches, loss of sensitive information, potential compliance violations, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker leverages misconfigured AWS permissions to access confidential data stored in Athena query results, exposing sensitive information to unauthorized entities.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper anonymization, sensitive data within datasets can be exposed to unauthorized individuals, leading to potential data breaches and privacy violations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and careless or untrained employees. Attack vectors range from direct access to the AWS Athena service without proper anonymization protocols to intercepting data in transit.
Impacts
Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive information, potential legal and compliance violations, loss of customer trust, and significant financial penalties.
Example Attack Scenarios
Scenario 1: An employee queries a dataset in AWS Athena that contains unmasked Personally Identifiable Information (PII). The data is inadvertently shared or accessed by an unauthorized party, leading to a data breach.
Scenario 2: An external attacker leverages a misconfigured access control policy to retrieve sensitive data from AWS Athena, which was not properly anonymized, and uses the data for malicious purposes.

weakness.name: CWE-15
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-15: External Control of System or Configuration Setting One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user. Allowing external control of system settings can disrupt service or cause an application to behave in unexpected, and potentially malicious ways.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-89
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

countermeasure.name: Configure origin access control to restrict CloudFront distribution access
countermeasure.desc: To enhance the security of your AWS CloudFront distributions, implement Origin Access Control (OAC) to restrict access to your origin servers. By configuring OAC, you ensure that only CloudFront has the necessary permissions to fetch content from the origin, preventing unauthorized access and modifications. This control involves creating an OAC, attaching it to your CloudFront distribution, and configuring your origin server (e.g., S3 bucket, custom origin) to only accept requests signed with the OAC signature. Regularly review and update OAC settings to align with any changes in your security posture or application architecture. Refer to AWS CloudFront Security Best Practices for detailed configuration steps and requirements.

reference.name: Restrict access to an AWS origin

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS for all data transmission and redirect HTTP to HTTPS
countermeasure.desc: To secure data transmitted between CloudFront and both viewers and origin servers, ensure that all communication is encrypted using HTTPS. Configure your CloudFront distribution to automatically redirect all incoming HTTP requests to HTTPS, preventing unencrypted data transmission. This can be achieved by setting up a custom error response for HTTP requests or by enforcing HTTPS in the CloudFront behavior settings. By enforcing HTTPS and redirecting HTTP traffic, you protect sensitive information from being intercepted, ensuring secure communication across your entire CloudFront distribution.

reference.name: Require HTTPS for communication between viewers and CloudFront

countermeasure.name: Implement signed URLs and signed cookies to restrict content access
countermeasure.desc: To ensure that only authorized users can access specific resources served by your AWS CloudFront distribution, use signed URLs and signed cookies. Signed URLs are ideal for granting temporary access to individual files, while signed cookies allow access to multiple restricted files. Configure these mechanisms to include expiration dates and IP whitelisting to further control access. Generate and manage the cryptographic keys securely to prevent unauthorized use. By implementing signed URLs and signed cookies, you can effectively restrict content access, protecting your resources from unauthorized distribution or consumption.

reference.name: Serve private content with signed URLs and signed cookies

countermeasure.name: Integrate AWS WAF with CloudFront to mitigate web exploits
countermeasure.desc: To protect your AWS CloudFront distribution from common web exploits such as SQL injection and cross-site scripting (XSS), integrate AWS Web Application Firewall (WAF) with CloudFront. AWS WAF allows you to create custom rules that filter and monitor HTTP and HTTPS requests based on defined conditions. Implement predefined managed rule groups for comprehensive protection against known vulnerabilities, and configure custom rules tailored to your applications specific security requirements. Regularly review and update your WAF rules to adapt to evolving threats, ensuring that your CloudFront distribution remains secure against web-based attacks.

reference.name: Security in Amazon CloudFront

countermeasure.name: Utilize version control for CloudFront configuration management
countermeasure.desc: Implement version control to manage and track changes to your AWS CloudFront distribution configurations. This practice allows you to maintain a history of configuration changes, making it easier to identify, audit, and revert any unintended or harmful modifications. Use tools such as AWS CloudFormation, Terraform, or Git to version your configuration files, enabling consistent and repeatable deployments. In case of a misconfiguration or security issue, version control provides a straightforward path to roll back to a previous stable state, ensuring the reliability and security of your CloudFront distribution.

reference.name: Use file versioning to update or remove content with a CloudFront distribution

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to CloudFront distribution
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unauthorized access to a CloudFront distribution occurs when an attacker gains access to the CloudFront distribution settings or content without proper authorization. This can lead to the manipulation of distribution settings, theft of sensitive data, or disruption of services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors: Compromised AWS credentials, insufficient access controls, exposed API keys.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized users may access or steal sensitive content.
  • Integrity: Attackers could modify distribution settings or content, leading to the distribution of malicious or incorrect information.
  • Availability: Attackers may disrupt services by altering or disabling the distribution.
  • Reputation: Loss of customer trust and potential legal consequences from data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker uses compromised AWS credentials to access and alter CloudFront settings, redirecting users to malicious content.
  2. Scenario 2: Insufficient access controls allow a former employee to log in and disrupt the CloudFront distribution, causing service outages.
  3. Scenario 3: An exposed API key is exploited to access CloudFront configurations, resulting in unauthorized changes to content delivery.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Data leakage through unencrypted data in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data leakage occurs when sensitive information is transmitted over the network without encryption. In AWS CloudFront, this happens when data moves between edge locations, clients, or origin servers using insecure protocols like HTTP, making it vulnerable to interception.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, state-sponsored actors, competitors.
  • Attack Vectors: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing, compromised network infrastructure.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data like login credentials and personal information.
  • Integrity: Potential alteration of data in transit.
  • Reputation: Damage to brand trust and legal repercussions.
  • Financial Loss: Regulatory fines, litigation costs, and loss of business.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker intercepts unencrypted HTTP traffic on public Wi-Fi to steal user credentials.
  2. Scenario 2: Unencrypted software updates are intercepted and maliciously altered.
  3. Scenario 3: A state-sponsored actor intercepts unencrypted corporate data, leading to espionage.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1032 - Standard Cryptographic Protocol

threat.name: Misconfigured CloudFront distributions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description Misconfigured CloudFront distributions can lead to serious security vulnerabilities, such as unauthorized access, data exposure, or service disruptions. These misconfigurations may include improper access settings, insecure SSL/TLS configurations, or incorrect origin server permissions, making the distribution susceptible to attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, careless administrators.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploitation of public S3 buckets, unauthorized access to CloudFront distributions, insecure SSL/TLS settings.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized users.
  • Integrity: Potential modification of data served by CloudFront.
  • Availability: Disruptions in service or unintended public access to private content.
  • Reputation: Damage to brand image due to security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An S3 bucket linked to CloudFront is left publicly accessible, allowing attackers to download sensitive files.
  2. Scenario 2: A misconfigured SSL/TLS setting allows attackers to perform a MitM attack, intercepting data between the client and CloudFront.
  3. Scenario 3: Origin server permissions are too broad, allowing unauthorized users to alter content served by CloudFront.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Content tampering
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Content tampering occurs when an attacker alters the content delivered through a CloudFront distribution. This can involve modifying or injecting malicious code, defacing web pages, or changing the data served to end-users. Such tampering can lead to a variety of harmful outcomes, including the distribution of malware, misinformation, or unauthorized data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploitation of vulnerabilities in origin servers, unauthorized access to CloudFront configurations, man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks.

Impacts

  • Integrity: Altered content can mislead users, distribute malware, or damage trust.
  • Reputation: Users may lose trust in the organization due to the distribution of tampered or harmful content.
  • Legal and Compliance: Organizations may face legal action or fines if tampered content results in harm to users or violates regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker gains unauthorized access to the origin server and modifies the web application files, causing users to download malware.
  2. Scenario 2: A hacker intercepts and alters data being transmitted from the origin to CloudFront, leading to the delivery of defaced or misleading content.
  3. Scenario 3: A malicious insider modifies content on an origin server that is distributed via CloudFront, resulting in the display of unauthorized or offensive material.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1492 - Stored Data Manipulation

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-664
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime The product does not maintain or incorrectly maintains control over a resource throughout its lifetime of creation, use, and release.

countermeasure.name: Enable automated image scanning for ECR repositories
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain a secure container environment in AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry), configure automated image scans to detect vulnerabilities in container images upon push and on a regular schedule. This helps identify and mitigate potential security threats before deploying images.

Enable Image Scanning on Push:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to your ECR repositories and enable the "Scan on Push" option. This setting ensures that each image is automatically scanned for vulnerabilities as soon as it is pushed to the repository.

Schedule Regular Image Scans:

  • Use AWS ECR's built-in capabilities to schedule periodic re-scans of all images. This is important for detecting newly discovered vulnerabilities in already stored images.

Set Up Notifications for Vulnerability Findings:

  • Configure Amazon SNS (Simple Notification Service) to send alerts for critical vulnerabilities detected in images. Integrate these notifications with your security information and event management (SIEM) tools or incident response workflows.

Review and Act on Scan Reports:

  • Regularly review vulnerability reports generated by ECR image scans. Prioritize remediation efforts for high and critical severity findings to minimize security risks.

Implement Automated Remediation Actions:

  • Integrate image scanning results with CI/CD pipelines to automatically block the deployment of images with high-severity vulnerabilities until they are resolved.

reference.name: Scan images for software vulnerabilities in Amazon ECR

countermeasure.name: Enable notifications for key ECR repository events
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and monitoring of AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry), configure ECR to send notifications for key repository events such as image push, pull, or deletion activities. This helps in promptly detecting unauthorized access or suspicious activities and allows for immediate response.

Set Up Amazon SNS for Notifications:

  • Create an Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS) topic to handle notifications for ECR events. Ensure the SNS topic is configured to send alerts via email, SMS, or integrate with other monitoring tools as needed.

Configure ECR Event Rules:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the ECR service and set up event rules for important repository actions. Specify events such as image push, pull, and deletion activities to trigger notifications.

Integrate with CloudWatch Events:

  • Use Amazon CloudWatch Events to capture ECR repository events and route them to the SNS topic. This integration allows for real-time monitoring of repository activities and automated alerts.

Customize Notification Settings:

  • Tailor notification settings to match your organizations security requirements. For example, set high-priority alerts for image deletions or pulls from unexpected IP addresses or regions.

reference.name: Amazon ECR events and EventBridge

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS for all communications with ECR
countermeasure.desc:
To secure data in transit and prevent interception, ensure that all communications with AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) use HTTPS. This encrypts the data transferred between ECR and other services or clients, protecting it from eavesdropping and tampering by malicious actors.

Require HTTPS for ECR Endpoints:

  • Configure all client applications, scripts, and automation tools interacting with AWS ECR to use HTTPS endpoints (https://) rather than HTTP. This ensures that all API calls and data transfers are encrypted.

Enforce Secure Protocols:

  • Update all Docker clients and other tools that interact with ECR to support and use only secure protocols, ensuring compatibility with HTTPS. Avoid using outdated or insecure versions of Docker that do not enforce HTTPS.

Restrict Direct Internet Access:

  • For environments that do not require public internet access, use VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) to connect to ECR securely without traversing the public internet. This further enhances the security of data in transit by keeping traffic within the AWS network.

Monitor Network Traffic for Compliance:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail and VPC Flow Logs to monitor network traffic and ensure that all communications with ECR repositories are using HTTPS. Set up alerts for any traffic detected over non-secure HTTP connections.

reference.name: Security in Amazon Elastic Container Registry

countermeasure.name: Implement lifecycle policies for automated image retention management
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain control over AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) repository contents and reduce the risk of accidental deletion, configure lifecycle policies to automate image retention management. This ensures that only relevant and necessary images are retained, optimizing storage and enhancing security.

Define Lifecycle Policies:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to your ECR repository and create lifecycle policies to specify image retention rules. Define policies based on image tags, age, or count to ensure that older, unused, or untagged images are automatically removed.

Set Retention Criteria:

  • Establish criteria for retaining images, such as keeping only the latest versions, retaining images used in production, or keeping images for a specified period (e.g., 30 days). Ensure these criteria align with your organizations deployment and security policies.

Apply Policies to Repositories:

  • Apply the defined lifecycle policies to all relevant ECR repositories to automate the cleanup process and prevent the accumulation of outdated or unused images.

Monitor and Adjust Policies:

  • Regularly review lifecycle policy logs and adjust policies as needed to accommodate changes in deployment practices, security requirements, or business needs.

Integrate with DevOps Workflows:

  • Ensure that lifecycle policies are integrated with your DevOps workflows to avoid unintentional removal of images required for CI/CD pipelines. Communicate policy details to development teams to align image usage with retention rules.

reference.name: Automate the cleanup of images by using lifecycle policies in Amazon ECR

countermeasure.name: Use resource-based policies to control access to ECR repositories
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) repositories, use resource-based policies to control access, ensuring that only authorized users and roles have the necessary permissions to interact with the repositories. This helps prevent unauthorized access and actions such as pulling, pushing, or deleting container images.

Define Resource-Based Policies:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the ECR service and create resource-based policies for each repository. These policies should specify who (users, roles, AWS accounts) can access the repository and what actions (e.g., push, pull, delete) they are allowed to perform.

Grant Least Privilege Access:

  • Configure the policies to follow the principle of least privilege, granting only the necessary permissions required for users or roles to perform their specific tasks. Avoid using overly broad permissions that could lead to unauthorized access.

Restrict Cross-Account Access:

  • If cross-account access is required, specify the exact AWS accounts and IAM roles that are allowed access to the ECR repository. Use conditions within the policy to restrict access based on specific criteria such as IP addresses or request time.

Apply and Review Policies Regularly:

  • Apply the resource-based policies to each ECR repository and regularly review them to ensure they align with the current security requirements and organizational policies. Update the policies as needed to accommodate changes in user roles or security needs.

Monitor Access and Usage:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail and Amazon CloudWatch to monitor access to ECR repositories and log all interactions. Set up alerts for any unauthorized access attempts or changes to repository settings.

reference.name: Private repository policies in Amazon ECR

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Insecure deletion of repository resources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Insecure Deletion of Repository Resources" refers to the risk of accidental or malicious deletion of container images and repositories in AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) without proper authorization or safeguards. This could result in the loss of critical container images, disruption of application deployments, and potential security vulnerabilities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, negligent administrators, external attackers with unauthorized access.
  • Vectors:
    • Misconfigured IAM policies allowing unauthorized or overly broad deletion permissions.
    • Lack of lifecycle policies or version control, leading to accidental deletions.
    • Exploitation of compromised credentials with deletion access.

Impacts:

  • Data Loss: Permanent deletion of critical container images, resulting in the inability to deploy or rollback applications.
  • Operational Disruption: Deletion of images can disrupt CI/CD pipelines, causing delays in application deployments and service outages.
  • Security Risks: Deletion of secure, trusted images could lead to the deployment of unvetted or compromised images.
  • Compliance Issues: Uncontrolled deletions may violate data retention policies or regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Accidental Deletion: An administrator mistakenly deletes a repository containing critical images due to a lack of lifecycle management or version control, causing significant deployment issues.
  • Malicious Insider Action: A disgruntled employee with deletion access intentionally deletes key images from ECR, disrupting application deployments and causing potential security breaches.
  • Compromised Account: An attacker uses compromised credentials with deletion permissions to remove important images, leading to application downtime and security exposure.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Use of vulnerable container images
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Using vulnerable container images in AWS ECR can expose applications to security risks. Vulnerabilities may come from outdated software, insecure dependencies, or malicious code within the images, allowing attackers to exploit these weaknesses.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, automated bots.
  • Vectors:
    • Pulling images from untrusted or public sources.
    • Deploying images without vulnerability scans.
    • Using outdated base images or insecure dependencies.

Impacts:

  • Security Breach: Exploitation of vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access or execute malicious code.
  • Data Leakage: Unauthorized access to sensitive data within compromised containers.
  • Operational Disruption: Potential for Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks or performance degradation.
  • Compliance Violations: Non-compliance with security regulations due to using unpatched images.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Outdated Image Exploit: An unpatched base image with a critical vulnerability is exploited, allowing an attacker to gain control over the container.
  • Malware in Unscanned Image: A container image containing malware is deployed without a security scan, leading to data exfiltration.
  • Insecure Dependencies: A container uses outdated libraries, which are exploited by attackers to access the backend database and steal sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1609 - Container Administration Command

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to ECR repositories
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Unauthorized Access to ECR Repositories" refers to the risk of unauthorized users gaining access to AWS ECR (Elastic Container Registry) repositories. This unauthorized access could lead to actions such as pulling, pushing, or deleting container images without proper authorization, potentially compromising the security and integrity of applications.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized external users.
  • Vectors:
    • Misconfigured IAM policies or repository permissions allowing overly broad access.
    • Exploitation of compromised credentials with elevated privileges.
    • Inadequate use of resource-based policies, allowing unintended access.

Impacts:

  • Security Breach: Unauthorized users could pull sensitive or proprietary images, exposing them to external threats.
  • Data Manipulation: Attackers might push malicious images or delete critical images, leading to the deployment of compromised containers.
  • Operational Disruption: Deletion or tampering with images could disrupt application deployment pipelines, causing downtime.
  • Compliance Violations: Unauthorized access can lead to non-compliance with data protection and security standards.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Compromised Credentials: An attacker uses compromised credentials to access an ECR repository and pulls sensitive container images, exposing proprietary code or configurations.
  • Overly Permissive Policies: A repository is configured with overly permissive IAM policies that inadvertently grant public access, allowing unauthorized users to pull or push images without restriction.
  • Insider Threat: A malicious insider with unauthorized access to ECR repositories deletes critical images or replaces them with tampered versions, leading to potential security breaches and operational issues.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Insecure data transfer
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Insecure Data Transfer" refers to the risk of data being transmitted between AWS ECR and other services without adequate encryption. If data is transferred over insecure channels, it can be intercepted, modified, or stolen by malicious actors, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Vectors:
    • Transmitting data between ECR and other services without using HTTPS.
    • Misconfigured network settings that allow unsecured communication.
    • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks exploiting unencrypted traffic.

Impacts:

  • Data Breach: Interception of sensitive data in transit, such as container images, credentials, or configuration details.
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Modification of data during transfer, leading to corrupted or maliciously altered images.
  • Service Disruption: Potential for unauthorized access or manipulation of container images, impacting service availability.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Intercepted Credentials: An attacker intercepts unencrypted traffic between ECR and a client, capturing sensitive credentials used for authentication and gaining unauthorized access.
  • Man-in-the-Middle Attack: A MitM attack is executed on unsecured communications, allowing an attacker to modify container images in transit, injecting malicious code.
  • Unauthorized Access via Unsecured Connection: An insider exploits a misconfigured network setting to access and download sensitive images from ECR without proper authorization.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of monitoring of repository activities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Lack of Monitoring of Repository Activities" refers to the absence of adequate logging and monitoring for actions taken within AWS ECR repositories. Without proper monitoring, unauthorized access, suspicious activities, or potential security incidents such as unauthorized image pushes, pulls, or deletions may go undetected.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, negligent administrators.
  • Vectors:
    • Lack of configured logging for ECR repository actions.
    • No alerting mechanisms for critical events such as unauthorized access attempts or deletions.
    • Insufficient visibility into repository activities, leading to undetected malicious actions.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized Access: Lack of detection for unauthorized access attempts, potentially compromising repository security.
  • Data Loss: Undetected deletions or modifications of container images can lead to data loss or deployment of compromised images.
  • Compliance Violations: Failing to monitor repository activities may result in non-compliance with regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Undetected Unauthorized Access: An external attacker gains unauthorized access to an ECR repository but remains undetected due to lack of monitoring, allowing for repeated unauthorized activities.
  • Malicious Insider Deletion: A disgruntled insider deletes critical images from the repository. Without monitoring, the action is not immediately noticed, causing operational disruptions.
  • Image Tampering: An attacker modifies images within the repository to inject malicious code. Due to insufficient monitoring, these changes go unnoticed until the compromised images are deployed.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1565.003 - Runtime Data Manipulation

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-664
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime The product does not maintain or incorrectly maintains control over a resource throughout its lifetime of creation, use, and release.

weakness.name: CWE-691
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-691: Insufficient Control Flow Management The code does not sufficiently manage its control flow during execution, creating conditions in which the control flow can be modified in unexpected ways.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-79
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Conduct regular vulnerability scans on container images
countermeasure.desc: Implement a routine process to scan container images for vulnerabilities using tools like Amazon ECRs native scanning capabilities or third-party solutions like Clair and Trivy. Configure these scans to run automatically when new images are pushed to the registry and on a regular schedule for existing images. This proactive approach helps in early detection and remediation of potential security threats, ensuring that containerized applications are protected against known vulnerabilities.

reference.name: Amazon ECS task and container security best practices

PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Configure containers with read-only root file systems
countermeasure.desc: Enhance container security by setting the root file system to read-only, which prevents any modifications by malicious actors. This configuration blocks unauthorized writes to the root file system, reducing the risk of malicious changes or software installations. Implement this setting in your container orchestration tool (like Docker or Kubernetes) by specifying the readOnlyRootFilesystem parameter in your container definitions. Regularly verify this setting during container audits to maintain a secure deployment environment.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt container images with customer-managed keys
countermeasure.desc: Enhance the confidentiality of container images stored in Amazon Elastic Container Registry (ECR) by encrypting them with customer-managed keys (CMKs) via AWS Key Management Service (KMS). Configure your ECR repositories to utilize CMKs for encryption instead of the default AWS-managed keys. This practice gives you control over the encryption keys and policies, allowing for more stringent security measures and compliance with organizational standards for data protection. Regularly review and rotate your CMKs to maintain security integrity.

countermeasure.name: Enforce CPU and memory limits on ECS tasks
countermeasure.desc: To maintain optimal resource availability and system stability within your Amazon VPC, it is crucial to set and enforce appropriate CPU and memory limits on your ECS tasks. Define these limits in the task configuration to prevent any single task from consuming excessive system resources, which could impact other operations. Use the AWS Management Console or AWS CLI to specify cpu and memory parameters for each task definition. Regular monitoring and adjustments based on performance metrics are recommended to ensure the settings meet your operational needs.

countermeasure.name: Implement immutable tags for image integrity in Amazon ECR
countermeasure.desc: Ensure the authenticity and integrity of container images stored in Amazon Elastic Container Registry (ECR) by using immutable tags. This configuration prevents accidental or malicious overwrites of images by disallowing changes to tags once they are assigned to an image version. Set the immutability option in the ECR repository settings to enable this feature. This practice helps maintain a reliable and secure supply chain for container deployments. Regularly review tagging strategies to align with best practices for image versioning and updates.

countermeasure.name: Implement minimalist container images
countermeasure.desc: To minimize the attack surface within your Amazon VPC, ensure that all container images are minimalist, containing only the essential application code and its runtime dependencies. Use tools like Docker Slim or multi-stage builds in Docker to strip unnecessary packages, files, and binaries from your images before deployment. Regularly review and update these images to ensure they include only what is necessary for the application to function, enhancing overall security posture.

countermeasure.name: Implement static code analysis in development lifecycle
countermeasure.desc: Integrate static code analysis tools into your software development lifecycle to proactively identify and remediate security flaws in the source code. Configure these tools to automatically scan code commits in your version control system (e.g., GitHub, Bitbucket) as part of your CI/CD pipeline. This practice helps in early detection of vulnerabilities, such as SQL injection or cross-site scripting, thus preventing potential exploits in production environments. Regularly update the rulesets of these tools to cover the latest security threats.

countermeasure.name: Reduce container attack surface by stripping unneeded capabilities
countermeasure.desc: Minimize security risks by configuring containers to operate with the least privileges necessary, stripping unneeded capabilities that could be exploited in an attack. Use Linux capabilities to manage and restrict the rights granted to containers. Tools such as Docker can specify dropped capabilities in container runtime configurations. Regularly audit and update the list of capabilities to ensure it aligns with the evolving security landscape and the specific needs of your applications.

countermeasure.name: Restrict container image permissions
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that container images are configured with the minimal set of permissions necessary for their operation. Use the principle of least privilege when setting up roles and permissions in your container orchestration platform, such as Amazon ECS. Define specific IAM roles for each container or service that grant only the required permissions for tasks they need to perform. Regular audits and reviews of permissions should be conducted to eliminate excess privileges that could be exploited by attackers.

countermeasure.name: Restrict containers from running with privileged status
countermeasure.desc: To enhance security within your Amazon VPC, ensure that containers deployed on Amazon ECS do not run with privileged status. This practice prevents containers from accessing critical host resources, mitigating the risk of system-level compromises. Implement this control by setting the privileged parameter to false in your container definitions within the ECS task configuration. Regularly review and audit your ECS task definitions to enforce and verify this security setting, ensuring compliance across your deployments.

countermeasure.name: Run container processes as non-root users
countermeasure.desc: To limit the potential impact of a security breach, configure your container processes to execute as non-root users. This reduces the risk of privileged escalations. In the Dockerfile, use the USER instruction to specify a non-root user before running any commands. Ensure that this user has the appropriate permissions required to operate the application, and nothing more. Regularly review and tighten these permissions as part of your container security strategy.

countermeasure.name: Scan application dependencies for security vulnerabilities
countermeasure.desc: Regularly scan all application dependencies for known security issues to prevent exploitation. Use tools such as OWASP Dependency-Check or Snyk within your development pipeline to automate the scanning process. Configure these tools to trigger scans on code commits or during build processes. Update dependencies frequently based on the scan reports to mitigate any identified vulnerabilities, ensuring that your applications remain secure against known threats.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Resource exhaustion
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Resource exhaustion occurs when a system's resources, such as CPU, memory, or network bandwidth, are overwhelmed, typically by malicious intent. This can happen when excessive demands are placed on these resources, making the system slow or unresponsive.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attackers might employ scripts or bots to create a large number of tasks or services within Amazon ECS, or they might manipulate application processes to consume more resources than allocated. External attackers or malicious insiders could both exploit this vulnerability.

Impacts

Resource exhaustion can lead to denial of service (DoS), decreased application performance, and potential system crashes. In a cloud environment like ECS, it could also lead to increased costs due to resource scaling to meet the illegitimate demand.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker could deploy a container in ECS that purposely consumes an excessive amount of CPU and memory resources, affecting other containers running on the same cluster. Alternatively, an attacker could trigger a flood of requests that overwhelm the application, causing legitimate requests to time out or fail.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Privilege escalation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Privilege escalation occurs when an entity gains elevated access to resources that are normally protected from an application or user. This can happen when a user or process gains rights or permissions beyond those originally granted, potentially leading to unauthorized system access or control.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attack vectors could include exploiting vulnerabilities in software, misconfigurations in security settings, or compromising lower-level user accounts that interact with Amazon ECS. This could be orchestrated by external attackers or malicious insiders.

Impacts

The impacts of privilege escalation are severe and can include unauthorized data access, data manipulation, and persistent access to the system, which might compromise the entire ECS cluster. It may also lead to further attacks on connected systems.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker might exploit a vulnerability in an application running in a container, allowing them to execute commands as a root user. Alternatively, an attacker could use a stolen set of credentials to modify ECS task definitions to run arbitrary commands, thereby escalating privileges within the cluster.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Image integrity and confidentiality
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

This threat involves unauthorized alterations to container images or exposure of their contents. It can occur when images are not adequately secured, allowing attackers to inject malicious code or access sensitive data embedded in the images.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Attack vectors include compromised credentials, insecure image repositories, and man-in-the-middle attacks during image transfer. Both external attackers and malicious insiders with access to image repositories can pose a threat.

Impacts

Compromised image integrity can lead to the deployment of malicious containers, resulting in unauthorized actions within the infrastructure. Breaches of confidentiality can expose sensitive data, intellectual property, or regulatory-controlled information.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker could intercept an image during transfer and inject malicious code, which is then executed within the ECS environment when the container is run. Alternatively, an attacker with access to the image repository might alter an image to create a backdoor in applications deployed from it.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1525 - Implant Internal Image

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure container images
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure container images contain vulnerabilities or misconfigurations that can be exploited by attackers. These issues may arise from outdated software, inadequate security settings, or embedded malicious code.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers who might exploit known vulnerabilities or insiders who could introduce vulnerabilities intentionally. Common attack vectors are compromised image repositories or using unverified images from public registries.

Impacts

Using insecure images can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and persistent malware within the cloud infrastructure. The security and operational integrity of the entire ECS environment can be compromised.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker could push a compromised image to a public repository that is then used unknowingly in production environments, leading to system compromise. Alternatively, an outdated image could be deployed, containing vulnerabilities that attackers exploit to gain control over the container and associated services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1525 - Implant Internal Image

threat.name: Code vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Code vulnerabilities refer to flaws in software that can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access or cause harm. These vulnerabilities can exist in the application code itself or within the libraries and dependencies the application uses.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Potential exploiters include external attackers using known vulnerabilities and internal users inadvertently introducing vulnerable code. Common vectors include injection attacks, cross-site scripting (XSS), and outdated libraries with known exploits.

Impacts

Exploiting these vulnerabilities can lead to data breaches, unauthorized access, and other security incidents. The impact is often system compromise or data exposure, potentially leading to significant operational and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker might use a SQL injection vulnerability in application code running in an ECS container to extract sensitive database information. Alternatively, exploiting a known vulnerability in a third-party library could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code within the container.

component.name: Amazon Neptune
component.desc: Amazon Neptune, a fully managed graph database service.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-345
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-345: Insufficient Verification of Data Authenticity The product does not sufficiently verify the origin or authenticity of data, in a way that causes it to accept invalid data.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Configure AWS CloudTrail to monitor and log API Calls made by Neptune's service-linked roles
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure detailed audit trails for actions performed on Neptune resources, configure AWS CloudTrail to monitor and log API calls made by Neptune's service-linked roles. This not only strengthens the security posture but also provides insights into activities affecting Neptune resources.

Implementation Guidance:

  1. Navigate to the AWS CloudTrail Console.
  2. Create a new trail or select an existing trail that will log API activities.
  3. Ensure that the trail is applied to all regions to capture global API activity for comprehensive auditing.
  4. Configure the trail to log Management Events, which include API calls made by Neptunes service-linked roles.
  5. To log data events specifically for Neptune, refer to the CloudTrail documentation on logging data events.
  6. Specify an S3 bucket for storing log files, and configure appropriate permissions to ensure that the logs are secure and accessible only by authorized personnel.
  7. Enable CloudWatch Logs integration to facilitate real-time monitoring and alerting based on specific API activities.

Refer to the official AWS Neptune documentation for additional security practices: AWS Neptune Security Guidelines.

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption at rest
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon Neptune provides encryption at rest to protect your data and automated backups from unauthorized access. This can be achieved by leveraging the AWS Key Management Service (KMS) for key management. To implement this control, follow these steps:

  1. Create a new Neptune database instance with encryption: When creating a new DB instance, ensure encryption is enabled. You cannot enable encryption for an existing unencrypted DB instance.
  2. Choose a KMS key: Select an AWS KMS key to encrypt your data. You can either use the default AWS managed key or create a new customer-managed key (CMK) if you require more control over the keys.
  3. Automated backups: Automatically created backups, snapshots, and replicas of the encrypted Neptune DB instance will also be encrypted.
  4. Monitor encryption status: You can verify if your Neptune DB instance and backups are encrypted by using the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs.

For detailed steps and additional guidance, refer to the Amazon Neptune Encryption at Rest Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Ensure HTTP requests are signed with AWS Signature version 4
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure authenticity and integrity of all HTTP requests to Amazon Neptune resources with IAM database authentication enabled, it is imperative to sign each request using AWS Signature Version 4.

Implementation Guidance

This countermeasure helps secure communications by ensuring that requests are from legitimate sources and have not been tampered with in transit. Follow the steps below to implement this control:

1. Configure IAM Roles and Policies

Ensure that your IAM roles and policies are configured to allow actions on Neptune resources. For more details, refer to the Neptune IAM Documentation.

2. Enable IAM DB Authentication

To enable IAM DB authentication, configure your Neptune DB clusters accordingly. Detailed instructions can be found in the section IAM Database Authentication.

3. Sign HTTP Requests

  • Use AWS SDKs or AWS CLI, which support automatic signing of requests using AWS Signature Version 4.
    • For AWS CLI, ensure you have configured your credentials using AWS CLI Configuration.
    • For AWS SDKs, integrate the SDK into your application and ensure it is configured with your AWS credentials.
  • If you are manually constructing HTTP requests, you must sign them using the AWS Signature Version 4 signing process. Instructions are available in the AWS Signature Version 4 Signing Process.

By diligently following these steps and referencing the official AWS and Neptune documentation, you will enforce robust security measures that protect the integrity and authenticity of your communications with Amazon Neptune resources.

countermeasure.name: Use service-linked roles to grant appropriate permissions to AWS Neptune
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and ease the management of permissions for AWS Neptune, it is recommended to leverage service-linked roles. Service-linked roles are predefined IAM roles that include all the necessary permissions for Neptune to perform tasks on your behalf, thereby reducing the complexity of manually creating and managing IAM policies.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Ensure you have the necessary IAM permissions to create or modify service-linked roles in your AWS account.
  2. When setting up an AWS Neptune cluster, allow the service to create the necessary service-linked role. This role will follow the naming convention: AWSServiceRoleForAmazonNeptune.
  3. Review the policy attached to the service-linked role to understand the specific permissions granted. The policy will generally allow Neptune to perform actions such as accessing logs and monitoring data.
  4. Monitor and audit the use of service-linked roles regularly to ensure compliance with your organizations security policies.

Using service-linked roles ensures that only the required permissions are granted, thereby adhering to the principle of least privilege.

References:

For more detailed information, please refer to the official AWS Neptune security documentation:

  • Using Service-Linked Roles for Amazon Neptune
  • AWS Neptune Security Guidelines

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Neptune resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without appropriate Identity and Access Management (IAM) roles, there is a risk that unauthorized entities may gain access to Neptune resources. This could result in unauthorized data breaches or modifications, jeopardizing sensitive information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include external hackers, malicious insiders, or compromised user accounts. Attack vectors may involve exploitation of poorly configured IAM policies, stolen credentials, or lack of multi-factor authentication (MFA).
Impacts
Unauthorized access to Neptune resources can lead to data breaches, data loss, data corruption, and unauthorized data alterations. This can result in significant financial loss, reputational damage, and compliance violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could leverage weak IAM roles to gain unauthorized access to Neptune databases and exfiltrate sensitive data. A malicious insider could exploit excessive permissions to modify or delete critical data for personal gain or to cause harm.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data breach via unencrypted data at rest
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unencrypted data stored in the Neptune database could be accessed by unauthorized parties, leading to data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors who gain access to the Neptune database either through misconfigured access policies, stolen credentials, or by exploiting vulnerabilities in the database service.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive or confidential data, resulting in potential data breaches, loss of customer trust, legal penalties, and financial losses.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits a weak or default password to gain access to the database and retrieves unencrypted personal information, or an insider with legitimate access to the database extracts unencrypted data and sells it on the black market.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of traceability
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper role usage, tracking and auditing actions on Neptune resources become difficult, leading to insufficient accountability.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers could exploit misconfigured roles to access or modify Neptune resources undetected. Insiders might misuse their roles without being tracked.
Impacts
Data integrity and confidentiality could be compromised. It becomes challenging to identify malicious activities, leading to potential data leaks and unauthorized access.
Example Attack Scenarios
An insider with improper role permissions makes unauthorized changes to the database schema, affecting application functionality. An external attacker exploits unmonitored roles to exfiltrate sensitive data, causing data breaches.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unsigned HTTP requests
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unsigned HTTP requests to Amazon Neptune resources can be intercepted or tampered with, leading to unauthorized access and data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious attackers leveraging man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks or unauthorized network access to intercept or modify traffic being transmitted to and from Amazon Neptune.
Impacts
Potential exposure of sensitive data, unauthorized access to Neptune resources, data manipulation, and increased risk of data breaches and loss of integrity.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker intercepts an unsigned HTTP request sent to a Neptune instance, modifies the query, and gains unauthorized access to data, potentially exfiltrating sensitive information or manipulating the database content.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

countermeasure.name: Configure Amazon Cognito authentication for OpenSearch Dashboards
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure secure access to your Amazon OpenSearch dashboards, you can authenticate users using Amazon Cognito. This method allows you to take advantage of Amazon Cognito's user pools and identity pools to manage and authenticate users. Below are the steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Create an Amazon Cognito User Pool: Start by setting up a User Pool in Amazon Cognito. User Pools are user directories that provide sign-up and sign-in options for your application users. For more details, refer to the AWS documentation on Amazon Cognito User Pools.

  2. Create an Amazon Cognito Identity Pool: Establish an Identity Pool that enables you to obtain temporary AWS credentials for your users, thus allowing them to access AWS resources. You can link this Identity Pool to your User Pool in order to authenticate users with their credentials. For a comprehensive guide, see Amazon Cognito Identity Pools.

  3. Configure OpenSearch Security Settings: Navigate to the OpenSearch Service console. Under the security settings for your OpenSearch domain, choose Amazon Cognito for the authentication system. Fill in the User Pool ID and Identity Pool ID that you created in the previous steps. You will also need to configure the App Client ID and callback URLs. Detailed instructions are available at Authenticating Dashboard Users with Amazon Cognito.

  4. Verify and Test: Ensure that the setup is correctly implemented by testing the login flow. Access the OpenSearch Dashboards and verify you can securely log in using an Amazon Cognito authenticated user account.

For further information and security best practices, refer to the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation available at AWS OpenSearch Service Security.
