weakness.name: CWE-1190
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1190: DMA Device Enabled Too Early in Boot Phase The product enables a Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable device before the security configuration settings are established, which allows an attacker to extract data from or gain privileges on the product.

weakness.name: CWE-184
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-184: Incomplete List of Disallowed Inputs The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are not allowed by policy or otherwise require other action to neutralize before additional processing takes place, but the list is incomplete, leading to resultant weaknesses. Developers often try to protect their products against malicious input by performing tests against inputs that are known to be bad, such as special characters that can invoke new commands. However, such lists often only account for the most well-known bad inputs. Attackers may be able to find other malicious inputs that were not expected by the developer, allowing them to bypass the intended protection mechanism.

countermeasure.name: Deploy CodeBuild projects within a VPC for network isolation
countermeasure.desc: Deploy AWS CodeBuild projects within a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) to ensure that build environments are isolated from external networks, thereby reducing exposure to external threats. Configure your VPC with appropriate security groups and network access control lists (ACLs) to control inbound and outbound traffic to the build environments. This setup ensures that only authorized internal resources can communicate with the CodeBuild environment, enhancing the security of the build process. Additionally, leverage VPC endpoints for secure access to AWS services without traversing the public internet. Implementing this control helps safeguard your build environments against unauthorized access and network-based attacks.

reference.name: Use AWS CodeBuild with Amazon Virtual Private Cloud

countermeasure.name: Encrypt build artifacts at rest in S3
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all build artifacts generated by AWS CodeBuild are stored in Amazon S3 with encryption enabled at rest. This prevents unauthorized access to sensitive data by protecting the artifacts using AWS-managed encryption keys (SSE-S3) or customer-managed keys (SSE-KMS). To implement this control, configure the S3 bucket that stores your build artifacts to enable server-side encryption (SSE) by default. Review and validate that all existing and new artifacts are encrypted at rest. This practice helps maintain the confidentiality and integrity of your build outputs, mitigating the risk of data breaches.

countermeasure.name: Enforce strict input validation in build scripts
countermeasure.desc: Implement strict validation of all inputs used within AWS CodeBuild scripts to prevent code injection attacks. Ensure that any parameters, environment variables, or external data consumed by build scripts are thoroughly validated for correctness, format, and security. Incorporate validation checks within the build scripts to sanitize inputs, rejecting any malformed or potentially malicious data before it is processed. Use allowlists, regular expressions, and secure coding practices to further reduce the risk of injection vulnerabilities. This control helps maintain the integrity and security of your build process by preventing unauthorized code execution.

reference.name: Security in AWS CodeBuild

countermeasure.name: Regularly update build environments with latest patches and software versions
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS CodeBuild environments are consistently updated with the latest security patches and software versions. This includes regularly reviewing and applying updates to the underlying operating systems, libraries, and dependencies used within your build environments. Automate the update process where possible by utilizing AWS services such as AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager or incorporating patching steps into your CI/CD pipeline. Regularly verify that your build environments are up-to-date to minimize vulnerabilities and protect against potential security threats. Maintaining current software versions is critical for the security and stability of your build processes.

Utilize the principle of least privilege by granting the minimum necessary permissions for accessing, modifying, or managing the build artifacts. Additionally, consider enabling logging and monitoring of access to these S3 buckets using AWS CloudTrail and Amazon S3 access logs to detect any unauthorized access attempts. Proper access control ensures the confidentiality and integrity of your build artifacts.

usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Sensitive data in logs
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data in logs occurs when confidential information, such as credentials or personal data, is inadvertently recorded in AWS CodeBuild logs. This can lead to unauthorized access if the logs are improperly secured or accessed by unauthorized parties.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, unauthorized users, or external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Accessing logs that contain sensitive data.
    • Exploiting insufficient log sanitization processes to retrieve confidential information.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information leading to potential data leaks or identity theft.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust and credibility if sensitive data is exposed.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of data protection regulations, possibly resulting in legal penalties and fines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Access: An attacker gains access to CodeBuild logs and extracts exposed API keys or credentials, which they then use to compromise other systems.
  2. Internal Data Leak: A developer inadvertently logs sensitive customer information, which is later accessed by an unauthorized internal user, leading to a data breach.
  3. Compliance Breach: Logs containing personal data are accessed without proper controls, violating data protection laws and resulting in regulatory action.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Insufficient network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insufficient network isolation in AWS CodeBuild occurs when the build environment is not properly segregated from other network resources. This lack of isolation exposes the build environment to potential external threats, allowing unauthorized access, data leakage, or interference with build processes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, compromised internal systems, or malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of network misconfigurations to gain access to the build environment.
    • Lateral movement from other compromised resources within the same network.

Impacts

  • Security Breach: Unauthorized access to the build environment, leading to potential data theft or code tampering.
  • Operational Disruption: Interference with build processes, potentially resulting in failed builds or deployment of compromised code.
  • Compliance Risks: Non-compliance with security standards requiring network segmentation, possibly leading to regulatory fines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. External Attack: An attacker exploits an unprotected network segment to gain access to CodeBuild and injects malicious code into the build pipeline.
  2. Lateral Movement: A compromised server within the same network is used to access and tamper with the build environment due to lack of network segmentation.
  3. Data Exfiltration: An attacker intercepts sensitive data transmitted between the build environment and other resources due to inadequate network isolation.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Code injection via build scripts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Code injection via build scripts occurs when an attacker or unauthorized user introduces malicious code into the build scripts used by AWS CodeBuild. This malicious code can then be executed during the build process, potentially compromising the integrity of the build, leaking sensitive data, or introducing vulnerabilities into the final software product.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised CI/CD systems.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Inserting malicious code directly into build scripts or configurations.
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities in third-party dependencies or plugins used in the build process.

Impacts

  • Compromised Software Integrity: Malicious code could be embedded in the final software product, leading to security vulnerabilities or backdoors.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive information might be extracted and sent to unauthorized parties during the build process.
  • Operational Disruption: The build process could be sabotaged, resulting in failed builds or deployment of insecure code.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Script Manipulation: An attacker gains access to the build script repository and injects malicious code that exfiltrates sensitive data during the build process, which is then sent to an external server.
  2. Third-Party Dependency Exploit: A malicious actor exploits a vulnerability in a third-party library or plugin integrated into the build script, leading to the execution of unauthorized code during the build.
  3. Insider Attack: A disgruntled employee inserts malicious code into the build scripts, which, once deployed, opens a backdoor in the application for future exploitation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

threat.name: Compromised build environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

A compromised build environment occurs when an attacker gains unauthorized access to the infrastructure or resources used by AWS CodeBuild. This can result in the manipulation of the build process, introduction of malicious code, or exposure of sensitive data. A compromised build environment undermines the security of the entire CI/CD pipeline and can lead to severe downstream impacts on deployed applications.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised third-party tools.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in the build environment or associated infrastructure.
    • Unauthorized access due to weak security controls or misconfigurations in the build environment.

Impacts

  • Integrity Loss: Unauthorized modifications to the build process or outputs, leading to the deployment of compromised or malicious software.
  • Data Exposure: Leakage of sensitive information, including source code, credentials, and configuration files.
  • Operational Disruption: Interruption or sabotage of the build process, causing delays or deployment of flawed applications.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Infrastructure Exploit: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the underlying infrastructure hosting the build environment, gaining control over the build process and inserting malicious code into the final product.
  2. Misconfiguration Abuse: Due to a misconfiguration, an unauthorized user gains access to the build environment, modifies build scripts, and causes the deployment of compromised software.
  3. Third-Party Tool Compromise: A third-party tool integrated into the build environment is compromised, allowing an attacker to manipulate the build process or steal sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain

threat.name: Unauthorized access to build artifacts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access to build artifacts occurs when individuals or entities gain access to the files, binaries, or other outputs generated by AWS CodeBuild without proper authorization. This can lead to the exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized code changes, or distribution of compromised software.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, unauthorized internal users, or compromised build systems.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting misconfigured S3 bucket permissions where build artifacts are stored.
    • Gaining access through over-permissioned IAM roles associated with the build environment.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive or proprietary code and data contained in build artifacts.
  • Operational Risk: Deployment of compromised or altered software, leading to potential security vulnerabilities.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust if compromised artifacts are distributed.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Misconfigured S3 Bucket: An attacker exploits a publicly accessible S3 bucket containing build artifacts, downloads the artifacts, and discovers sensitive information or injects malicious code.
  2. Internal Misuse: An insider with excessive permissions accesses build artifacts and modifies them, leading to the deployment of unauthorized code in a production environment.
  3. Artifact Tampering: An attacker gains access to artifacts stored in an insecure location, alters the files, and these compromised files are later deployed, resulting in a security breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1500 - Compile After Delivery

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-346
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-346: Origin Validation Error The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

weakness.name: CWE-613
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-613: Insufficient Session Expiration According to WASC, "Insufficient Session Expiration is when a web site permits an attacker to reuse old session credentials or session IDs for authorization."

countermeasure.name: Apply fine-grained identity policies
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and ensure precise control over user access to resources, implement fine-grained identity policies using AWS Cognito. This approach involves creating specific IAM policies that tightly control what authenticated and unauthenticated users can access.

Begin by defining user roles and associating them with appropriate IAM policies. For instance, authenticated users might have policies granting them access to user-specific resources, whereas unauthenticated users might have restricted access.

Here's a step-by-step guide for a cloud engineer:

  1. Create an IAM Role for Authenticated Users
    • Navigate to the IAM console and create a new role for authenticated users.
    • Attach a policy to this role that grants permissions to access only specific resources. Use JSON policy documents for greater precision. Refer to the Cognito IAM roles documentation for example policies.
  2. Create an IAM Role for Unauthenticated Users
    • Similarly, create another role for unauthenticated users, ensuring the policy attached to this role is more restrictive.
  3. Associate Roles with Cognito Identity Pool
    • Navigate to the Cognito console and choose your identity pool.
    • Edit the identity pool settings to assign the roles created above to authenticated and unauthenticated users respectively.
  4. Test the Policies
    • Validate that authenticated users have the correct level of access and that unauthenticated users are appropriately restricted.

For more detailed information, refer to the AWS Cognito security guidelines and specific references on IAM roles.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management

countermeasure.name: Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of user accounts in AWS Cognito, it is highly recommended to enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA). By integrating MFA, an additional layer of protection is provided, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. Follow the guidelines below to implement MFA for your Cognito user pool:

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console and navigate to the Amazon Cognito service.
  2. Select the user pool for which you want to enable MFA.
  3. In the left-hand navigation pane, choose MFA and verifications.
  4. Under the Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) section, configure your desired MFA settings:
    • Set the MFA status to Optional or Required based on your security needs.
    • Select the MFA methods you wish to enable, such as SMS or TOTP (Time-based One-Time Password).
  5. Configure the SMS or TOTP settings accordingly. For SMS, ensure you have an appropriate SMS role with sufficient permissions. For TOTP, users will need to register their compatible authenticator application.
  6. Save the changes to the user pool settings.

Following these steps will significantly enhance the security posture of your user accounts by leveraging MFA. For further information on configuring MFA with AWS Cognito, refer to the official documentation: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) in Amazon Cognito.

Additional detailed security considerations can be explored in the AWS Cognito Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to sensitive user attributes
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing access control for sensitive user attributes in AWS Cognito is essential to enhance security and ensure that such attributes are only accessible by authorized users or services. Follow these guidelines to appropriately restrict access:

Step-by-Step Implementation:

  1. Define Sensitive User Attributes: Identify and label sensitive user attributes in your user pool. These could include PII (Personally Identifiable Information) such as email addresses, phone numbers, or any custom attributes that hold sensitive information.
  2. Configure User Pool Policies: Utilize Amazon Cognitos user pool settings to specify which attributes are sensitive and should have restricted access. This can be configured in the user pool attributes settings.
  3. Leverage IAM Policies: Create and enforce IAM policies for the roles and users accessing the user pool. Ensure that these policies adhere to the principle of least privilege, granting the minimum required permissions to access necessary attributes. More details on setting up secure policies can be found in the IAM policy examples.
  4. Use Amazon Cognito Contextual Data: Implement the use of contextual information (such as IP addresses, device types, etc.) to enhance security conditions under which an attribute can be accessed or modified. This approach helps mitigate unauthorized access from unexpected locations or devices.
  5. Audit and Monitor Access: Regularly audit and monitor access to sensitive user attributes using Amazon CloudWatch and AWS CloudTrail. Enable logging and set up alerts for any suspicious or unauthorized access attempts. Refer to the Cognito Streams documentation for guidance on setting up logging and monitoring.
  6. Implement Encryption: Ensure that sensitive user attributes are encrypted both in transit and at rest. AWS Cognito provides built-in encryption for user data at rest, but ensure that transport layer encryption such as TLS is configured correctly for your user pool endpoints. More information can be found in the encryption documentation.

By following these steps and utilizing the features provided by AWS Cognito, cloud engineers can effectively limit access to sensitive user attributes, ensuring that only authorized users or services can access this information. For comprehensive security practices and guidelines, refer to the AWS Cognito Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Set up proper session validity periods
countermeasure.desc:
To configure appropriate session validity periods and refresh token policies in AWS Cognito and thereby minimize the window of opportunity for session-based attacks, a cloud engineer should follow these steps:

  • Set Appropriate Session Timeout:

To mitigate potential session-based attacks, it is crucial to configure appropriate session timeout settings. AWS Cognito allows you to set the session duration through the app client settings. Navigate to the AWS Cognito console, select your user pool, and go to the "App clients" settings. Here, configure the Refresh Token Expiration and Token Expiration values to an appropriate timeframe based on your security requirements.

Refer to the following documentation for detailed instructions: AWS Cognito Token Endpoint Documentation.

  • Implement Refresh Token Rotation:

For enhanced security, implement a refresh token rotation policy. This means generating a new refresh token every time the refresh operation is performed. AWS Cognito supports refresh token rotation to further minimize the window in which a stolen token could be used. In the AWS Cognito console, under your user pool settings, enable the PreventUserExistenceErrors option, and configure the refresh token rotation as needed.

For more details, refer to the official security documentation: AWS Cognito Security Best Practices.

  • Regularly Review and Update Policies:

Frequently audit and update your session validity periods and refresh token policies to ensure they align with current security best practices and the evolving threat landscape. This proactive approach helps to continually minimize potential attack vectors.

Consult the following official resource for guidance: AWS Cognito Security Best Practices.

By carefully configuring session validity periods and refresh token policies following AWS Cognito security guidelines, you can significantly reduce the risk of session-based attacks on your applications.

standard.ref: PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Validate JWT tokens
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the proper validation of JWT tokens and confirm their authenticity and integrity, cloud engineers should implement the following countermeasures based on the official AWS Cognito documentation:

1. Verify the Signature: AWS Cognito issues JWT tokens that are signed using a key. To verify the signature, you must use the JSON Web Key Set (JWKS) provided by AWS Cognito. Retrieve the JWKS from the provided URL and use it to validate the token's signature. Reference: AWS Cognito - Verifying a JSON Web Token.

2. Check the Token Expiration: Inspect the "exp" claim in the JWT to ensure that the token has not expired. This check prevents the use of tokens past their validity period, mitigating the risk of replay attacks. Reference for security measures: AWS Cognito Security.

3. Validate the Audience (aud) Claim: The "aud" claim should match the expected audience value configured in your application. This ensures that the token was issued for your specific application and not an unintended audience. Reference: AWS Cognito Security Documentation.

4. Verify the Issuer (iss) Claim: Ensure that the "iss" claim matches the expected issuer URL for your AWS Cognito user pool. This confirms that the token was issued by your trusted user pool. Reference: Verifying a JWT - AWS Cognito.

5. Validate the Token Claims: In addition to the above claims, validate any other token claims that your application relies on for authorization, such as "sub" for user ID and custom claims included in the token. Reference: Security guidelines for AWS Cognito.

6. Regularly Update Your JWKS: AWS rotates the signing keys periodically. Ensure your implementation can handle key rotation by regularly fetching the JWKS and updating your verification mechanisms accordingly. Reference: Using and Verifying Tokens.

By following these guidelines, cloud engineers can robustly validate JWT tokens, ensuring their authenticity and integrity, and thereby significantly enhance the security posture of applications leveraging AWS Cognito.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data exposure due to misconfigured tokens
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper management of tokens can lead to exposure of sensitive information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised applications can intercept or misuse improperly managed tokens.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to user accounts, unauthorized actions within user contexts, and potential data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker intercepts a token transmitted over an insecure channel and uses it to gain unauthorized access to a user account. Alternatively, an insider with access to token storage leverages the token to perform unauthorized actions within the application.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Inadequate authorization controls
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured authorization policies can allow users to gain access to resources they should not have access to, potentially leading to data manipulation or leakage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or malicious insiders exploiting weak or misconfigured authorization policies to gain access to sensitive data or resources illegally.
Impacts
Data breach, unauthorized data modification, loss of data integrity, and potential legal and financial repercussions for failing to protect sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers a misconfiguration in AWS Cognito authorization policies that grant excessive permissions. By exploiting this, they access confidential customer data, modify records, and exfiltrate sensitive information, leading to significant harm to the organization's reputation and financial standing.

threat.name: Exposed user attributes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured user attribute policies can lead to exposure of sensitive personal information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors may exploit misconfigurations in user attribute policies to access, alter, or extract sensitive information stored within AWS Cognito.
Impacts
This can result in unauthorized access to PII (Personally Identifiable Information), leading to privacy violations, data breaches, and potential financial and reputational damage to the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers that email addresses and phone numbers are set to be publicly readable in the User Pool. By leveraging this misconfiguration, they can harvest this sensitive information for phishing attacks or identity theft. Another scenario might involve an insider modifying attribute policies to expose additional sensitive attributes without proper authorization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1531 - Account Access Removal

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Compromised accounts due to poor multi-factor authentication (MFA)
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without multi-factor authentication (MFA), accounts become susceptible to unauthorized access if credentials are phished or otherwise compromised.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can use phishing schemes, social engineering tactics, or exploit credential leaks from other breaches to gain access to an account.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and potentially damaging modifications or deletions of user data and application settings.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker successfully phishes an AWS Cognito user's credentials through a convincing email. Without MFA in place, the attacker uses the compromised credentials to log in and access the account, leading to unauthorized data access and potential exploitation of the user's information.

threat.name: Insufficient session management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Poor session management can lead to session hijacking or replay attacks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit poorly managed sessions, particularly if session identifiers are predictable, not rotated frequently, or not securely stored.
Impacts
Successful exploitation can result in unauthorized access to user accounts, data breaches, and potential financial loss, damaging the companys reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker captures a user's session token through a man-in-the-middle attack or by accessing logs where tokens are stored improperly. The attacker then uses the token to impersonate the user and gain unauthorized access to sensitive resources.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Configure secure external storage for AWS Config data
countermeasure.desc:
When leveraging external storage locations for AWS Config data, it is crucial to ensure these locations are properly secured in compliance with AWS security best practices. This countermeasure involves multiple steps:

  1. Enable Encryption at Rest: Ensure that the external storage location supports and uses strong encryption for data at rest. AWS Config data should be encrypted using AWS Key Management Service (KMS) or another secure encryption service offered by the external provider.
    • Reference: AWS Config - Secure Data at Rest
  2. Use Secure Transport: Data in transit to the external storage must be encrypted using secure transport protocols such as HTTPS/TLS. This helps prevent interception and man-in-the-middle attacks.
    • Reference: AWS Config - Secure Data in Transit
  3. Access Control: Apply strict access control policies to the external storage location. Utilize IAM roles and policies to restrict access to only those services or users who require it. Additionally, implement multi-factor authentication (MFA) for accessing sensitive data.
    • Reference: AWS Config - Access Control
  4. Regular Auditing: Regularly audit access logs and configurations of the external storage to ensure compliance with security policies. Use AWS Config rules to continuously monitor the configurations and enforce compliance.
    • Reference: AWS Config - Auditing
  5. Data Integrity Controls: Implement mechanisms to verify the integrity of the AWS Config data stored externally. Use checksums or hash functions to detect unauthorized modifications.
    • Reference: AWS Config - Data Integrity

countermeasure.name: Confirm and verify delivery channels
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that delivery channels are correctly set up in AWS Config and that the service is recording resources as expected, follow these steps:

  • Set Up Delivery Channels:

First, make sure you have at least one delivery channel configured in AWS Config. A delivery channel specifies details about where AWS Config delivers configuration snapshots and configuration history files. You can create or update a delivery channel using the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDK.

For more information, refer to Managing AWS Config Delivery Channels.

  • Verify Configuration Recorder:

Ensure that the configuration recorder is enabled and properly configured. This is essential for capturing the configuration changes of your AWS resources. Navigate to the AWS Config console and check that the configuration recorder is active and recording the resources you've specified.

Details can be found here: Managing the Configuration Recorder.

  • Validate Resource Recording:

To confirm that AWS Config is recording the resources as expected, review the recorded configurations and compliance status of your resources. Regularly check AWS Config console or use AWS CLI commands to make sure all intended resources are being tracked and that there are no gaps in recording.

For comprehensive guidance, see Evaluating AWS Resource Configurations with AWS Config.

  • Enable Notifications:

Set up Amazon SNS notifications to receive alerts about configuration changes. This ensures that you are promptly informed about any changes to your AWS resources configurations. Configure SNS topics and subscriptions as needed.

Refer to Monitoring AWS Config with Amazon SNS for additional details.

  • Review and Audit Regularly:

Regularly audit your AWS Config settings and delivery channels to ensure continuous compliance with your security policies and to adhere to best practices. Conduct periodic checks to ensure that everything is set up and operating as required.

Best practices for auditing AWS Config can be found in the official documentation AWS Config Security Best Practices.

By following these steps, you can ensure that AWS Config delivery channels are correctly set up and the service is recording resources effectively, aligning with AWS security best practices.

countermeasure.name: Enable continuous monitoring of configuration changes
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure continuous compliance with best practices, it is crucial to leverage AWS Config rules for monitoring and evaluating configuration changes. Follow these steps to implement this control effectively:

  1. Enable AWS Config in your AWS account by navigating to the AWS Management Console, selecting AWS Config, and following the setup wizard to specify the resources you want to track and the Amazon S3 bucket for storing configuration snapshots.
  2. Create AWS Config rules to define desired configurations and compliance standards. You can choose from the pre-built rules provided by AWS or create custom ones to meet specific requirements. For detailed instructions, refer to the AWS Config documentation on evaluating resource configurations.
  3. Configure the rules to continuously monitor resources by setting the appropriate triggers, such as configuration changes or periodic evaluations. Ensure that the rules are set to remediate non-compliant resources automatically if necessary, by attaching AWS Systems Manager Automation documents.
  4. Review and analyze the compliance reports generated by AWS Config. These reports provide insights into the status of your resources and help identify areas that need attention. Utilize the AWS Config console for a comprehensive overview of compliance status.
  5. Leverage the integration with AWS CloudTrail to track API calls and detect changes in resource configurations. This integration enhances your ability to investigate and respond to unauthorized changes. Refer to the AWS Config and AWS CloudTrail integration guide for more details.

By following these steps and utilizing AWS Config rules, you can achieve continuous monitoring and compliance with best practices, significantly enhancing your cloud security posture. For more information, refer to the AWS Config security documentation.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt AWS Config data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that data collected by AWS Config is protected against unauthorized access, it is essential to apply AWS Key Management Service (KMS) for encryption. AWS Config supports encrypting data at rest using AWS KMS keys. Follow the steps below to configure AWS KMS for your AWS Config:

Set up a Customer Master Key (CMK) in AWS KMS:

Navigate to the AWS KMS console and create a CMK by following the steps delineated in the AWS KMS Developer Guide. Ensure that the CMK policies are configured to grant the necessary permissions for your AWS Config.

Apply the CMK to AWS Config:

AWS Config uses the KMS key to encrypt configuration data at rest. To ensure AWS Config uses your CMK, update the AWS Config settings to specify the KMS key ARN that you have created. For detailed instructions on applying the CMK to AWS Config, refer to the guidance provided in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

Verify Permissions:

Confirm that AWS Config has the necessary permissions to use the KMS CMK. The AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) roles or users associated with AWS Config should have the necessary kms:Encrypt and kms:Decrypt permissions for the CMK in its policy. Refer to the section on IAM roles for AWS Config for comprehensive information on configuring IAM permissions.

Enable AWS Config:

Once you have set up the CMK and granted the appropriate permissions, enable AWS Config and specify the KMS key ARN in the AWS Config settings. Detailed guidance is available in the Setting Up AWS Config documentation.

By following these steps, you can securely encrypt the configuration data collected by AWS Config, thereby mitigating the risk of unauthorized data access. For additional security recommendations and best practices, consult the AWS Config Developer Guide's Security and Compliance section.

reference.name: 2.3.1 - Ensure that encryption is enabled for EFS file systems

countermeasure.name: Require logging of all AWS Config rule changes
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS Config setup, it is essential to leverage the AWS Config rule history to monitor changes to rules and detect any unauthorized modifications. This countermeasure strengthens your cloud environment by ensuring that any changes in the AWS Config rules are tracked and reviewed. The following steps guide a cloud engineer on how to implement this control:

  • Enable AWS Config:

First, ensure that AWS Config is enabled in your AWS environment. Refer to the official documentation for setting up AWS Config: Setting Up AWS Config.

  • Configure Rule History:

AWS Config automatically keeps a history of rule evaluations. To access and review the rule history, navigate to the AWS Config console and go to the Rules section. From there, select a specific rule to view its configuration changes and history.

  • Monitor Changes:

Regularly review the AWS Config rules history to identify any unauthorized modifications. This can be done through the AWS Config console, where you can view detailed change logs for each rule.

  • Automate Alerts:

Set up Amazon CloudWatch alarms or AWS Config notifications to alert administrators of specific changes in AWS Config rules. This ensures timely detection and response to unauthorized activities. Detailed guidance on configuring notifications can be found here: Monitoring AWS Config with Amazon CloudWatch.

  • Audit and Compliance:

Additionally, integrate AWS Config rule history reviews into your regular security audits and compliance checks. This helps in maintaining a secure and compliant cloud environment. Refer to the auditing guidelines provided by AWS: Ensuring Compliance with AWS Config.

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to AWS Config snapshots
countermeasure.desc:
To apply AWS IAM policies to control who can view, modify, or delete AWS Config snapshots, follow these steps to ensure that only authorized users have the necessary permissions:

  1. Navigate to the IAM service in the AWS Management Console.

  2. Create an IAM policy that defines the permissions for viewing, modifying, and deleting AWS Config snapshots. Use the following JSON policy document as a template:

    {
            "Version": "2012-10-17",
            "Statement": [
                {
                    "Effect": "Allow",
                    "Action": [
                        "config:DeliverConfigSnapshot",
                        "config:DescribeConfigurationRecorders",
                        "config:DescribeConfigurationRecorderStatus",
                        "config:GetComplianceDetailsByConfigRule",
                        "config:GetComplianceSummaryByConfigRule",
                        "config:DescribeConfigRuleEvaluationStatus",
                        "config:DescribeConfigRules",
                        "config:DescribeConfigurationAggregatorSourcesStatus",
                        "config:DescribeConfigurationAggregators",
                        "config:DescribeAggregationAuthorizations",
                        "config:SelectResourceConfig"
                    ],
                    "Resource": "*"
                }
            ]
        }

  3. Attach this policy to an IAM user, group, or role that requires the specified permissions.

  4. Test the permissions by logging in with an account that has the newly attached policy and attempting to view, modify, or delete AWS Config snapshots. Ensure that unauthorized actions are appropriately blocked.

For detailed guidance on restricting AWS Config access, refer to the AWS Config Developer Guide: Restricting Access to AWS Config.

Additionally, for overall security best practices and information, see the "Security in AWS Config" section in the AWS Config Developer Guide: Security in AWS Config.

countermeasure.name: Use external ID for role assumption
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your cross-service roles and prevent confused deputy attacks when using AWS Config, it's critical to specify an external ID. This ensures that only the correct, intended AWS service can assume the role.

Heres a step-by-step guide on implementing this control:

  1. Create or Edit the IAM Role:
    • Go to the IAM console.
    • Select 'Roles' from the navigation pane.
    • If creating a new role, click 'Create role' and select the AWS service that will assume this role. If editing an existing role, choose the role from the list.
  2. Specify Trust Relationships:
    • In the role trust policy, add or modify the policy to include the sts:ExternalId condition. This must match the external ID provided by the trusted AWS service.
    • Example trust policy snippet: 
      {
    "Effect": "Allow",
    "Principal": {"Service": ".amazonaws.com"},
    "Action": "sts:AssumeRole",
    "Condition": {"StringEquals": {"sts:ExternalId": "external-id-value"}}
}
  3. Provide the External ID:
    • Share the external ID with the trusted AWS service or external party that requires access. Ensure this is done securely.

Following these steps helps mitigate the risk of confused deputy attacks by ensuring that only the intended AWS service can assume the IAM role with the specified external ID. For more detailed information and security guidelines, refer to the official AWS documentation on Cross-Service Confused Deputy Prevention and the AWS Config Security Page.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Cross-service confused deputy attacks
threat.desc:
General threat description
In a cross-service confused deputy attack, an attacker can trick a more privileged service into performing actions on their behalf, potentially leading to unauthorized access or changes.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors exploit the trust relationships between different AWS services by manipulating the requests in a way that makes a privileged service act on their behalf. This often involves the misuse of IAM roles and policies.
Impacts
Successful attacks can result in unauthorized access to sensitive data, unauthorized modifications of resources, execution of unintended code, and potentially significant financial costs as a result of misuse of cloud resources.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a compromised low-privilege service to send a request to a more privileged service, leveraging an overly permissive IAM policy. The privileged service then performs sensitive actions such as accessing confidential data stored in S3 buckets, initiating EC2 instances, or modifying security group rules on behalf of the attacker.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1528 - Steal Application Access Token

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure external data storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing AWS Config data in insecure external locations can lead to data breaches and unauthorized access.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit misconfigurations or weaknesses in external storage locations to gain unauthorized access to AWS Config data.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to AWS Config data can result in data breaches, loss of sensitive configuration information, and potential compliance violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attack may occur if AWS Config data is stored in an unsecured S3 bucket with improper access controls, allowing an attacker to access and exfiltrate the data. Another scenario could involve misconfigured permissions on a third-party storage service that inadvertently exposes the data to unauthorized users.

threat.name: Insufficient data protection
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate protection of data collected by AWS Config can result in unauthorized access to sensitive information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include malicious insiders, external attackers, or entities exploiting misconfigured AWS Config settings. Attack vectors may involve unauthorized access due to poor encryption practices, lack of proper IAM policies, or network vulnerabilities leading to data breaches.
Impacts
Impacts of inadequate data protection can include exposure of sensitive information, potential regulatory fines, loss of customer trust, and considerable financial and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits improperly configured IAM policies to gain access to AWS Config data, leading to the exposure of sensitive information such as compliance reports and resource configurations. In another scenario, a malicious insider downloads unencrypted AWS Config data stored in an S3 bucket and sells it on the dark web, compromising organizational security.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to AWS Config snapshots
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to AWS Config snapshots can expose historical configuration data, potentially leading to security risks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include external attackers or malicious insiders who gain unauthorized access to AWS Config snapshots through misconfigured access policies or stolen credentials. Attack vectors could involve exploiting weak or improperly managed IAM roles or permissions.
Impacts
The exposure of historical configuration data can lead to significant security risks, including the ability to understand configurations over time, potentially revealing vulnerabilities, non-compliance with internal policies, or regulatory requirements. Additionally, this data could be used to craft more sophisticated and targeted attacks on the AWS environment.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker exploits a vulnerability in an application with permissions to access AWS Config snapshots, subsequently gaining unauthorized access to the historical configuration data. 2. A compromised user account with insufficiently restricted permissions accesses and exfiltrates AWS Config snapshots, using the data to understand the organization's security posture and plan further attacks. 3. An insider with appropriate access permissions intentionally downloads and shares AWS Config snapshots, leading to a data leak and exposing sensitive configuration history.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1619 - Cloud Storage Object Discovery

threat.name: Improperly configured delivery channels
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigured delivery channels can result in AWS Config not recording resource configurations or changes, leading to gaps in compliance and security monitoring.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Misconfigured settings by users, insufficient access controls, or automated scripts with incorrect configurations.
Impacts
Gaps in compliance reporting, undetected configuration changes, reduced ability to track resource state over time, increased risk of security breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An administrator accidentally configures the delivery channel to point to a non-existent S3 bucket, leading to loss of recorded configuration data. 2. Automated scripts that provision cloud infrastructure misconfigure the delivery channel, resulting in an inability to monitor new resource configurations. 3. Insufficient access controls allow an unauthorized user to modify the delivery channel settings, disrupting the tracking of compliance and security-related data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of configuration changes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Failure to adequately monitor configuration changes can lead to unnoticed misconfigurations that pose security risks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include internal users with configuration access and external attackers who exploit vulnerabilities. Attack vectors involve unauthorized changes to configurations that go undetected.
Impacts
Impacts include potential unauthorized data access, data breaches, compliance violations, and compromised system integrity.
Example Attack Scenarios
An internal user maliciously alters security group rules to allow unrestricted access. Due to lack of monitoring, the change goes unnoticed, resulting in unauthorized data extraction by an external attacker who exploits the open access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

threat.name: Unauthorized config rule changes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized changes to AWS Config rules can lead to misconfigurations and potential security vulnerabilities in your AWS environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal actors such as employees or external attackers who have gained unauthorized access to the AWS management console or API.
Impacts
Misconfigurations in the AWS environment, leading to potential data breaches, compliance violations, and exposure to further attacks.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the AWS management console and modifies AWS Config rules to allow insecure resource configurations. This could weaken the security posture of the infrastructure, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive data or services.

countermeasure.name: Enable comprehensive data access logging
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS Cost Management, enable logging for all data access events to monitor and audit data usage and detect any unauthorized access. Implement AWS CloudTrail to capture and review access logs, ensuring all actions taken by users, roles, or AWS services are recorded.

Implementation Steps:

Enable CloudTrail: Set up AWS CloudTrail for your AWS account to capture API calls and access events related to AWS Cost Management.

Configure Logging: Ensure CloudTrail is configured to log all data access events, including read and write actions.

Store Logs Securely: Save the logs in a secure S3 bucket with proper access controls to prevent unauthorized access to log data.

Regular Review: Schedule regular reviews of CloudTrail logs to detect and investigate any unauthorized or suspicious access events.

Set Up Alerts: Configure CloudWatch Alarms to alert security teams of any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts detected in the logs.

countermeasure.name: Enforce secure data transfer methods
countermeasure.desc:
To protect data in transit within AWS Cost Management, ensure that all data transfers use secure methods such as HTTPS or SFTP. Regularly update configurations to enforce secure transfer protocols, preventing unauthorized access and data interception.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Secure Transfers: Set up data transfers using HTTPS for web-based communications and SFTP for file transfers.

Regular Updates: Periodically review and update transfer configurations to ensure they adhere to the latest security standards and protocols.

Audit Transfer Protocols: Conduct regular audits to verify that all data transfers use secure methods and no insecure protocols are in use.

User Training: Educate users on the importance of using secure transfer methods and how to configure them properly.

countermeasure.name: Implement data versioning for integrity
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS Cost Management data, implement data versioning to keep track of changes and ensure data integrity. Versioning helps identify unauthorized modifications and allows restoration of previous versions, maintaining accurate and reliable data sets.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Versioning: Configure data repositories (e.g., Amazon S3) to support versioning for all relevant data sets.

Automate Version Management: Use scripts or AWS Lambda to manage data versions, ensuring all changes are versioned and stored appropriately.

Monitor Changes: Regularly review version histories to detect and analyze changes, identifying any unauthorized modifications.

Audit and Review: Conduct periodic audits to ensure compliance with versioning policies and data integrity requirements.

countermeasure.name: Prohibit sensitive information in tags
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS Cost Management, ensure that tags do not contain sensitive information to prevent exposure through tag-based access. Implement regular audits to verify compliance with this policy.

Implementation Steps:

Define Tagging Policies: Establish and communicate policies that prohibit the inclusion of sensitive information in tags.

Automate Tag Validation: Use automated scripts or AWS Config rules to scan tags for sensitive data and enforce compliance with tagging policies.

Manual Audits: Regularly conduct manual audits to ensure tags do not contain sensitive information and adhere to established policies.

User Training: Educate employees on the risks and policies regarding sensitive information in tags.

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to Cost Management data sets
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS Cost Management data sets, limit access to authorized users by configuring appropriate access controls and regularly reviewing permissions. This ensures that only users with the necessary permissions can access sensitive financial data.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Access Controls: Set up access controls using AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) to restrict access to specific users and roles.

Use Least Privilege Principle: Assign permissions based on the principle of least privilege, granting users only the access they need to perform their job functions.

Regularly Review Permissions: Conduct regular reviews of user permissions and access logs to ensure compliance and adjust as necessary.

Monitor Access: Implement monitoring tools to track and log access to cost management data, ensuring unauthorized access attempts are detected and addressed.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to cost management data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access to AWS Cost Management data involves individuals gaining access to sensitive financial information without proper authorization. This can lead to data breaches, misuse of financial data, and compromised data integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Users: Employees with excessive or improperly managed permissions.
  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting vulnerabilities or using compromised credentials.
  • Misconfigurations: Incorrectly configured access controls and permissions.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive financial information.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaches of regulatory requirements and data protection laws.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust and credibility due to unauthorized data access.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Credentials: An attacker uses stolen credentials to access sensitive financial data in AWS Cost Management.
  2. Insider Threat: An employee with excessive permissions accesses and exfiltrates confidential financial data.
  3. Access Control Misconfiguration: Incorrect access controls allow broader access than intended, leading to unauthorized data retrieval.

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data in tags
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Exposure of sensitive data in tags within AWS Cost Management can lead to unauthorized access and data breaches. Tags, often used for resource organization, should not contain confidential information as they may be visible in logs and billing reports.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Users: Employees unintentionally or intentionally adding sensitive data to tags.
  • External Attackers: Hackers gaining access through compromised accounts or misconfigurations.
  • Automated Tools: Scripts that expose or misuse tag data.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information.
  • Compliance Violations: Exposure leading to non-compliance with data protection regulations.
  • Operational Risks: Misuse of exposed data disrupting operations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unintended Exposure: An employee includes customer PII in tags for easier identification, leading to exposure in billing reports accessible by various teams.
  2. Log Exposure: Tags containing sensitive data are included in logs, which are then accessed by unauthorized users or shared externally.
  3. Misconfigured Access: Tags with sensitive information are used in environments with misconfigured access controls, leading to broader exposure than intended.

threat.name: Insecure data transfers
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure data transfers in AWS Cost Management involve transmitting data over unencrypted or poorly secured channels, making it vulnerable to interception and unauthorized access. Ensuring secure data transfer methods is crucial to protect sensitive financial information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Intercepting data via network vulnerabilities or man-in-the-middle attacks.
  • Internal Threats: Employees transmitting data using insecure methods.
  • Misconfigurations: Incorrectly configured transfer protocols exposing data in transit.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive data during transmission.
  • Integrity Loss: Data can be tampered with during insecure transfers.
  • Compliance Issues: Failure to secure data in transit can lead to regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Man-in-the-Middle Attack: An attacker intercepts data being transferred over an unsecured HTTP connection, gaining access to sensitive financial information.
  2. Insecure API Usage: An employee uses an API endpoint that doesnt enforce HTTPS, exposing data to interception.
  3. Misconfigured SFTP: Data transferred using misconfigured SFTP without proper encryption settings, leading to potential data leakage.

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring of data access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insufficient monitoring of data access in AWS Cost Management can result in unauthorized activities going undetected, increasing the risk of data breaches and misuse of sensitive information. Effective monitoring is essential for identifying and responding to suspicious activities promptly.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Users: Employees accessing data without proper oversight or logging.
  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting the lack of monitoring to access and manipulate data undetected.
  • Misconfigurations: Incorrectly set up logging and monitoring tools leading to gaps in visibility.

Impacts

  • Undetected Data Breaches: Unauthorized access and data exfiltration without timely detection.
  • Non-Compliance: Failure to meet regulatory requirements for data access monitoring.
  • Operational Risks: Inability to quickly respond to and mitigate security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Internal Data Theft: An employee accesses and exfiltrates sensitive data without triggering any alerts due to insufficient monitoring.
  2. External Compromise: An attacker gains access through a compromised account and continues to extract information over time without being detected.
  3. Configuration Error: A misconfiguration in the monitoring setup leads to critical access logs not being captured, allowing unauthorized activities to go unnoticed.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Data tampering
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data tampering in AWS Cost Management involves unauthorized alteration of cost management data, compromising the integrity and reliability of financial reports and forecasts. Such actions can lead to inaccurate cost analysis and decision-making.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Users: Insiders with access to modify data.
  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting system vulnerabilities to alter data.
  • Automated Tools: Malicious scripts or malware modifying data without authorization.

Impacts

  • Data Integrity: Compromised accuracy and trustworthiness of financial data.
  • Operational Disruption: Incorrect data leading to faulty decisions and operational inefficiencies.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of credibility and trust due to tampered financial reports.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Insider Manipulation: An employee alters financial data to hide fraudulent activities, resulting in misleading financial reports.
  2. External Exploit: An attacker breaches the system and modifies cost data, causing inaccuracies in cost forecasting.
  3. Malware Attack: A malware script infiltrates the system, automatically altering data values and disrupting normal operations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1493 - Transmitted Data Manipulation

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Consider client-side encryption
countermeasure.desc:
We recommend that you plan your encryption strategy before implementing your table in DynamoDB. If you store sensitive or confidential data in DynamoDB, consider including client-side encryption in your plan. This way you can encrypt data as close as possible to its origin, and ensure its protection throughout its lifecycle. Encrypting your sensitive data in transit and at rest helps ensure that your plaintext data isnt available to any third party.

The AWS Database Encryption SDK for DynamoDB is a software library that helps you protect your table data before you send it to DynamoDB. It encrypts, signs, verifies, and decrypts your DynamoDB table items. You control which attributes are encrypted and signed.

reference.name: CWE-311: CWE-311

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Monitor DynamoDB operations using CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
CloudTrail can monitor both control plane events and data plane events. Control plane operations let you create and manage DynamoDB tables. They also let you work with indexes, streams, and other objects that are dependent on tables. Data plane operations let you perform create, read, update, and delete (also called CRUD) actions on data in a table. Some data plane operations also let you read data from a secondary index. To enable logging of data plane events in CloudTrail, you'll need to enable logging of data plane API activity in CloudTrail. See Logging data events for trails for more information.

When activity occurs in DynamoDB, that activity is recorded in a CloudTrail event along with other AWS service events in the event history. For more information, see Logging DynamoDB Operations by Using AWS CloudTrail. You can view, search, and download recent events in your AWS account. For more information, see Viewing Events with CloudTrail Event History in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

For an ongoing record of events in your AWS account, including events for DynamoDB, create a trail. A trail enables CloudTrail to deliver log files to an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) bucket. By default, when you create a trail on the console, the trail applies to all AWS Regions. The trail logs events from all Regions in the AWS partition and delivers the log files to the S3 bucket that you specify. Additionally, you can configure other AWS services to further analyze and act upon the event data collected in CloudTrail logs.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Config to monitor configuration changes and ensure compliance with security policies
countermeasure.desc:
Using AWS Config, you can continuously monitor and record configuration changes of your AWS resources. You can also use AWS Config to inventory your AWS resources. When a change from a previous state is detected, an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) notification can be delivered for you to review and take action. Follow the guidance in Setting Up AWS Config with the Console, ensuring that DynamoDB resource types are included.

You can configure AWS Config to stream configuration changes and notifications to an Amazon SNS topic. For example, when a resource is updated, you can get a notification sent to your email, so that you can view the changes. You can also be notified when AWS Config evaluates your custom or managed rules against your resources.

For an example, see Notifications that AWS Config Sends to an Amazon SNS topic in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB's encryption at rest to secure data stored in tables, backups, and streams
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB encrypts at rest all user data stored in tables, indexes, streams, and backups using encryption keys stored in AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS). This provides an additional layer of data protection by securing your data from unauthorized access to the underlying storage .

You can specify whether DynamoDB should use an AWS owned key (default encryption type), an AWS managed key, or a customer managed key to encrypt user data. For more information, see Amazon DynamoDB Encryption at Rest.

reference.name: CWE-311: CWE-311

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB Streams to monitor data plane operations
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB is integrated with AWS Lambda so that you can create triggerspieces of code that automatically respond to events in DynamoDB Streams. With triggers, you can build applications that react to data modifications in DynamoDB tables.

If you enable DynamoDB Streams on a table, you can associate the stream Amazon Resource Name (ARN) with a Lambda function that you write. Immediately after an item in the table is modified, a new record appears in the table's stream. AWS Lambda polls the stream and invokes your Lambda function synchronously when it detects new stream records. The Lambda function can perform any actions that you specify, such as sending a notification or initiating a workflow.

For an example, see Tutorial: Using AWS Lambda with Amazon DynamoDB Streams. This example receives a DynamoDB event input, processes the messages that it contains, and writes some of the incoming event data to Amazon CloudWatch Logs.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM policy conditions for fine-grained access control
countermeasure.desc:
When you grant permissions in DynamoDB, you can specify conditions that determine how a permissions policy takes effect. Implementing least privilege is key in reducing security risk and the impact that can result from errors or malicious intent.

You can specify conditions when granting permissions using an IAM policy. For example, you can do the following:

  • Grant permissions to allow users read-only access to certain items and attributes in a table or a secondary index.
  • Grant permissions to allow users write-only access to certain attributes in a table, based upon the identity of that user.

For more information, see Using IAM Policy Conditions for Fine-Grained Access Control.
