countermeasure.name: Use PrivateLink interface endpoints for Lambda and supporting services
countermeasure.desc:
Create interface VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) for AWS Lambda and every service the function relies onLambda control plane (com.amazonaws.<region>.lambda), Function URLs (com.amazonaws.<region>.lambda-url), and supporting endpoints such as S3, ECR API/ECR DKR, CloudWatch Logs, KMS, DynamoDB, SQS, or Kinesisso that all deployment, invoke, and dependency traffic stays on the AWS backbone instead of the public internet.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet selection choose at least two private subnets in different Availability Zones to give Lambda enough ENIs for scaling and AZ-level resilience.
  2. Provision endpoints create each endpoint with the AWS CLI or IaC:
    1. aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint \
         --vpc-id vpc-1234abcd \
         --service-name com.amazonaws.eu-west-1.lambda \
         --vpc-endpoint-type Interface \
         --subnet-ids subnet-a subnet-b \
         --security-group-ids sg-lambda-endpoints
  3. keep Private DNS enabled so the standard service hostname automatically resolves to the VPC-local IPs.
  4. Harden network access attach a security group that allows only TCP 443 from Lambda subnets or CI/CD hosts; block port 80 entirely.
  5. Apply endpoint policies restrict calls to the exact actions your workload needs (e.g., lambda:InvokeFunction, lambda:GetLayerVersion) and, if required, add aws:SourceVpce or aws:SourceVpc conditions for defense-in-depth.
  6. Lock function resource policies when using Function URLs or cross-account invokes, include StringEquals {"aws:SourceVpce":"vpce-"} so internet-sourced requests are rejected even if a public path exists.
  7. Validate from a private instance run dig lambda.<region>.amazonaws.com and confirm it returns a 10.x address; disable the NAT Gateway temporarily and verify that deployments and invokes still succeed.
  8. Monitor and audit enable VPC Flow Logs for the endpoint ENIs, set CloudWatch alarms on rejected flows, and add an AWS Config rule that flags production VPCs missing the Lambda endpoint.

PrivateLink keeps Lambda control-plane and data traffic inside AWS, reduces latency, simplifies firewall rules, and satisfies compliance mandates that prohibit internet egress for sensitive workloads.

References

  • Interface VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) for Lambda
  • AWS PrivateLink basics and best practices

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

countermeasure.name: Use temporary credentials via AWS STS
countermeasure.desc:
Give every Lambda function, service, CI/CD pipeline, and human operator an IAM role to assume rather than a static IAM user with access-key pairs. When a principal assumes the role, AWS Security Token Service (STS) hands back short-lived credentials (default 1 h) that AWS rotates automatically. This removes permanent secrets from code, cuts the blast radius of a leaked key, and lets you attach granular, least-privilege policies to each role.

Implementation steps

  1. Create purpose-built roles one per Lambda function (execution role) and one per developer or automation persona. Scope policies to the minimum actions and resources needed.
  2. Configure assumption paths
    • AWS services: add the service principal (e.g., lambda.amazonaws.com, codebuild.amazonaws.com) to the roles trust policy so it can call sts:AssumeRole.
    • Humans/federation: use IAM Identity Center, SAML, or OIDC to let users assume their role after MFA.
  3. Remove static keys disable or delete legacy IAM users and hard-coded keys; store only the role ARN in configuration.
  4. Set sensible session limits keep MaxSessionDuration low (15 min1 h for interactive work; 12 h for workloads).
  5. Monitor & audit enable CloudTrail and IAM Access Analyzer to track who assumes which role; alert on unexpected roles or unusually long sessions.

Adopting STS-based roles wipes out long-lived credentials, enforces just-in-time access, and aligns with AWS recommended security posture.

References

  • Temporary credentials with AWS STS
  • Best practices for AWS Lambda IAM roles

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: SingleAZ failure for VPC functions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions are placed in a VPC that spans only a single Availability Zone, an AZ outage (due to hardware failure, networking issues, or scheduled maintenance) renders those functions unable to access their ENIs, subnets, or dependent servicescausing complete service disruption.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • AWS Infrastructure Failures: Power, network, or hardware faults isolated to one AZ.
  • Misconfiguration: VPC subnet or NAT gateway deployment limited to a single AZ.
  • Capacity Events: AZspecific resource exhaustion (e.g., ENI limits reached) preventing new function attachments.

Impacts

  • Service Outage: Affected Lambdas cannot execute, disrupting APIs, event processing, or backend jobs.
  • Data Delays: Queues and streams back up, leading to timesensitive data loss or processing lag.
  • Operational Costs: Emergency redeployments or crossAZ workarounds consume engineering time and may incur extra charges.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. AZ Hardware Failure: A hardware fault knocks out networking in AZA; all Lambda functions in that singleAZ VPC lose ENI attachment and fail to process inbound events.
  2. NAT Gateway Capacity Spike: A DDoS flood targets the NAT gateway in the lone AZ, saturating its throughput; VPCbound Lambdas cant reach the internet for API calls.
  3. Planned AZ Maintenance: AWS schedules maintenance that briefly disables ENI provisioning in AZB; because all subnets reside there, no new Lambda invocations succeed until maintenance completes.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Outdated runtime environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Outdated runtime environments occur when Lambda functions continue using deprecated or unpatched language runtimes (e.g. old Node.js, Python, Java versions), missing security fixes and performance improvements.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers scanning for known CVEs, supplychain adversaries embedding exploits in dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting publicly documented vulnerabilities in EOL runtimes.
    • Injecting malicious payloads through outdated library transitive dependencies.
    • Leveraging insecure default configurations tied to legacy runtimes.

Impacts

  • Remote Code Execution: Attackers exploit CVEs to run arbitrary code in your functions.
  • Data Breach: Compromised functions expose sensitive input or environment data.
  • Service Disruption: Unpatched bugs cause function crashes or performance failures.
  • Compliance Risks: Use of unsupported runtimes may violate organizational or regulatory policies.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CVE Exploit: A function running Python2.7 is targeted with a known bufferoverflow exploit, allowing an attacker to execute shell commands.
  2. Dependency Hijack: An outdated Node.js runtime pulls in a vulnerable version of a logging library; an attacker injects malicious code via crafted log messages.
  3. Misconfiguration Crash: A Java8 function uses an old JDBC driver with memoryleak bugs, causing repeated OOM errors and denial of service under load.

threat.name: Overly broad IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly broad IAM permissions occur when AWS Lambda execution roles or associated policies grant more privileges than necessaryoften using wildcards for actions or resourcesexposing your functions to escalate privileges or access unrelated services.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised deployment pipelines, and external attackers using stolen credentials.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • IAM policies with "Action": "lambda:*" or "*" on "Resource": "*" attached to function roles.
    • Overpermissive trust relationships allowing any principal to assume the Lambda role.
    • Failure to apply leastprivilege when granting access to AWS services (S3, DynamoDB, IAM).

Impacts

  • Privilege Escalation: Functions can call APIs beyond their scope (e.g., creating or deleting roles).
  • Data Breach: Exfiltration of sensitive data from S3 buckets, databases, or Secrets Manager.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised functions pivot to other services or resources in your account.
  • Operational Disruption: Unintended changes to infrastructure, such as spinning up expensive resources or deleting critical stacks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. S3 Overreach: A Lambda role with s3:* on * is compromised; the attacker lists and downloads all buckets, harvesting PII.
  2. IAM Role Abuse: An overly broad iam:* permission lets a malicious function create a new admin user, granting full account control.
  3. Cost Shock: A function granted ec2:RunInstances and ec2:TerminateInstances is hijacked to spin up large fleets of instances, incurring massive charges and then deleting them to cover tracks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Credential compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Credential compromise in AWS Lambda occurs when the secrets, API keys, or IAM credentials used by functions are exposed or stoleneither through code, environment variables, or execution contextallowing attackers to impersonate or control your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, automated bots, thirdparty library leaks, compromised CI/CD pipelines
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Embedding secrets (AWS keys, database passwords) in function code or plaintext environment variables
    • Retrieving IAM role tokens from the Lambda execution environment via SSRF or metadataendpoint exploits
    • Exposing credentials in version control systems, build artifacts, or CloudWatch logs

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Function Invocation: Attackers invoke functions at will, potentially incurring costs or executing unwanted actions
  • Privilege Escalation & Lateral Movement: Stolen credentials grant access to other AWS services or higherprivilege roles
  • Data Exfiltration & Tampering: Sensitive data processed by Lambdas (e.g., PII, business logic) can be read or modified
  • Service Disruption & Financial Loss: Illicit use of credentials can flood queues, trigger throttling, or bill for large-scale invocations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hardcoded Key Leak: A developer commits a Lambda function with embedded AWS keys to GitHub. An attacker clones the repo, uses the keys to read S3 buckets, and exfiltrates customer data.
  2. Metadata Endpoint Abuse: A malicious library loaded into the Lambda execution environment makes HTTP calls to the IMDS endpoint, harvesting the functions IAM role token and using it to spin up new EC2 instances.
  3. Log Exposure: A misconfigured logging library prints database credentials from environment variables to CloudWatch Logs; a compromised IAM principal with logs:GetLogEvents reads the logs and uses the credentials to drop the database.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1550.001 - Application Access Token

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Lack of network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions share flat or overly permissive network configurationssuch as residing in default VPC subnets without segmentation or securitygroup restrictionsthey gain unfettered access to internal systems and the internet, increasing risk of lateral movement and data exfiltration.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Compromised function code, malicious insiders, or thirdparty dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting broad VPC subnet placement to reach databases, caches, or internal APIs.
    • Using SSRF or openredirect flaws within the function to pivot across network boundaries.
    • Leveraging unrestricted egress to exfiltrate data to attackercontrolled endpoints.

Impacts

  • Lateral Movement: Attackers breach internal resources (e.g., RDS, Redis) via the compromised functions network path.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive payloads or environment variables are sent out over the internet.
  • Service Compromise: Unauthorized access to microservices, service meshes, or backend systems, undermining confidentiality and integrity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Database Pivot: A stolen function token is used to invoke a Lambda in the default VPC, which then connects to an internal MySQL cluster on port3306 to dump data.
  2. Internal Reconnaissance: An attacker injects SSRF payloads into a function endpoint, causing it to scan internal HTTP management interfaces and map out privileged services.
  3. Covert Exfiltration: A compromised dependency causes the function to upload decrypted S3 objects to an attackers external SFTP server, bypassing network ACLs.

threat.name: Lack of resource tagging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Without consistent tagging, Lambda functions cant be programmatically identified for ownership, environment, or purposehindering cost tracking, security policy enforcement, and operational oversight.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators, uncontrolled automation, and rogue deployments.
  • Vectors:
    • CI/CD pipelines creating functions without required Environment or Owner tags.
    • Manual console creations that omit security or compliance tags.
    • Thirdparty tooling that doesnt enforce tagging standards.

Impacts

  • Visibility Gaps: Security teams cant quickly locate or audit sensitive functions.
  • Policy Evasion: Tagbased IAM or GuardDuty suppression rules fail to apply, allowing unauthorized access.
  • Cost Overruns: Untracked orphan functions incur unexpected charges.
  • Cleanup Challenges: Hard to identify and decommission unused or outdated functions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hidden Malicious Function: An attacker deploys a backdoor Lambda without Team or Project tagsescaping routine audits and persisting undetected.
  2. Policy Bypass: A compromised automation role creates a function lacking the Compliance=PCI tag, sidestepping strict IAM permissions tied to that tag.
  3. Orphaned Resources: A deprecated services Lambdas remain untagged; months later, they still run and bill but arent owned or monitored by any team.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data exposure at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data exposure at rest in AWS Lambda occurs when sensitive informationsuch as environment variables, function code packages, layers, or log snapshotsis stored unencrypted or with weak key management, making it accessible to unauthorized parties if storage systems are compromised.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised AWS credentials, and thirdparty service breaches.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Retrieving unencrypted Lambda environment variables or code bundles from S3/ECR.
    • Accessing /tmp storage on compromised execution hosts.
    • Downloading unencrypted CloudWatch log exports or Lambda layer artifacts.

Impacts

  • Secret Leakage: Exposed API keys, database passwords, or tokens.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of atrest encryption mandates (PCIDSS, HIPAA, GDPR).
  • Lateral Movement: Harvested credentials enable access to other AWS resources.
  • Reputational & Financial Damage: Data breach remediation costs and loss of customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. ECR Artifact Theft: An attacker with ECR read permissions pulls a Lambda image containing hardcoded secrets in its code, extracting them offline.
  2. S3 Snapshot Breach: Misconfigured S3 bucket hosts unencrypted function packages; adversaries download and inspect code to harvest environment variables.
  3. Log Export Exposure: A support engineer exports CloudWatch logs (including sensitive payloads) to an unencrypted S3 bucket, which is later accessed by unauthorized users.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data interception in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data interception in transit occurs when communication to or from Lambda functionssuch as API Gateway requests, servicetoservice calls, or event payloadsis sent without proper TLS or through misconfigured network paths, allowing adversaries to eavesdrop on or alter the data stream.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Network eavesdroppers, maninthemiddle attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Invoking Lambda over HTTP (API Gateway or Function URL) instead of HTTPS
    • Misconfigured VPC endpoints or transit gateways that dont enforce encryption
    • Disabling or improperly validating TLS in SDKs or custom HTTP clients

Impacts

  • Credential Theft: API keys, JWTs, or signed URLs in request headers can be captured
  • Payload Exposure: Sensitive event data (PII, business logic) is readable in flight
  • Message Tampering: Intransit modification of inputs or outputs leads to corrupted processing
  • Replay Attacks: Captured invocations can be resent to trigger unauthorized function executions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. API Gateway Misuse: A functions URL endpoint is configured for HTTP only. An attacker on the same network sniffs request bodies containing user credentials and session tokens.
  2. VPC Endpoint Bypass: Lambda communicates with an internal service through a VPC endpoint that doesnt require TLS. A compromised EC2 instance in the VPC intercepts and logs unencrypted RPC calls.
  3. TLS Downgrade in SDK: A custom Python client disables certificate verification when calling a Lambda-backed API; an attacker performs a MITM attack to inject malicious payloads into the functions execution.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

threat.name: Unauthorized invocation via public resource policies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly permissive Lambda resource policies (e.g. "Principal": "*") expose functions to anyone on the internet or any AWS account, allowing unauthorized parties to invoke them without credentials.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised thirdparty accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Resourcebased policies granting lambda:InvokeFunction to Principal: "*".
    • Crossaccount policies missing Condition: {"StringEquals": {"AWS:SourceAccount": ...}}.
    • Automated scanners discovering public ARNs and issuing invoke requests.

Impacts

  • Unauthenticated Execution: Attackers trigger functions at will, potentially running malicious logic.
  • Cost Overruns: Highvolume invocations rack up unexpected AWS charges.
  • Data Exposure & Tampering: Functions that read or write sensitive data can be abused to leak or corrupt information.
  • Downstream Disruption: Flooded event sources (queues, streams) or dependent services may be overwhelmed or fail.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Function Flood: An attacker discovers a public Lambda ARN and scripts thousands of InvokeFunction calls per minute, incurring heavy costs and throttling backend resources.
  2. CrossAccount Abuse: A partners account has open invocation rights; a malicious actor uses it to invoke a paymentprocessing Lambda with crafted payloads, creating fraudulent transactions.
  3. Data Leak via Unauthorized Payloads: A function tied to an S3 bucket runs on every invocation; by invoking it with custom payloads, an attacker tricks it into returning sensitive file contents in its response.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of audit logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda API calls (e.g., CreateFunction, UpdateFunctionCode, InvokeFunction) arent captured by CloudTrail or centralized logging, unauthorized or malicious activity goes unrecorded.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Malicious insiders or compromised roles making API calls
  • Automated tools invoking or updating functions without generating logs
  • Misconfigured CloudTrail trails or logdelivery failures

Impacts

  • Undetected Changes: Function code or configuration modifications arent noticed
  • Forensic Blind Spots: Incidents cant be reconstructed or attributed
  • Compliance Failures: Violation of auditlogging mandates (e.g., PCIDSS, HIPAA)

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker updates a paymentprocessing Lambda to include malicious logic; without CloudTrail logs, the change isnt traced.
  2. A rogue script purges function versions via the SDK; absent audit entries, the deletions go unnoticed until failures occur.
  3. CloudTrail misconfiguration drops InvokeFunction records; a compromised role invokes backdoor functions repeatedly without alerting security teams.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Bootstrap backdoor persistence in custom runtimes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Custom runtimes in AWS Lambda rely on a 'bootstrap' file as their entry point, executed before reaching the handler. Without proper monitoring, this file can be manipulated to include malicious logic, enabling persistence across deployments.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers with access to deployment processes can modify the 'bootstrap' file to execute unauthorized activities, such as exfiltrating data, establishing backdoors, or altering runtime functionality.
Impacts
The compromise of the 'bootstrap' file can lead to unauthorized data access, persistent backdoors in the runtime environment, and stealthy modifications that evade detection during typical security reviews.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker with deployment privileges embeds malicious code into the 'bootstrap' file that exfiltrates sensitive data to an external server. Despite subsequent changes to the main handler logic, the hidden backdoor remains operational, continuing its activity undetected across multiple deployments.

reference.name: Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor (July 11, 2025)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1494 - Runtime Data Manipulation

threat.name: Code integrity compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Malicious alteration of Lambda function code or its dependenciesvia compromised build pipelines, direct edits, or tainted layersinjects unauthorized logic into your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised CI/CD systems, supplychain attackers
  • Vectors: Backdoored build artifacts, console/API code edits, inclusion of malicious Lambda layers

Impacts

  • Unauthorized code execution under your functions IAM role
  • Data exfiltration or tampering of event payloads and backend resources
  • Lateral movement via calls to other AWS services
  • Reputational harm and remediation costs

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CI/CD Injection: An attacker hijacks the build server to insert a reverseshell payload into the deployment ZIP.
  2. Console Swap: A compromised admin replaces production handler code via the AWS Console, embedding dataexfiltration logic.
  3. Malicious Layer: A popular thirdparty layer bundles a cryptominer, which executes under your account when included.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Consider encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
You have the following options for protecting data at rest in Amazon S3:

  • Server-side encryption All Amazon S3 buckets have encryption configured by default, and all new objects that are uploaded to an S3 bucket are automatically encrypted at rest. Server-side encryption with Amazon S3 managed keys (SSE-S3) is the default encryption configuration for every bucket in Amazon S3. To use a different type of encryption, you can either specify the type of server-side encryption to use in your S3 PUT requests, or you can set the default encryption configuration in the destination bucket.

Amazon S3 also provides these server-side encryption options:

  • Server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (SSE-KMS)
  • Dual-layer server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (DSSE-KMS)
  • Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C)

For more information, see Protecting data with server-side encryption.

  • Client-side encryption Encrypt data client-side and upload the encrypted data to Amazon S3. In this case, you manage the encryption process, the encryption keys, and related tools. As with server-side encryption, client-side encryption can help reduce risk by encrypting the data with a key that is stored in a different mechanism than the mechanism that stores the data itself.

Amazon S3 provides multiple client-side encryption options. For more information, see Protecting data by using client-side encryption.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Cross-Region Replication
countermeasure.desc:
Although Amazon S3 stores your data across multiple geographically diverse Availability Zones by default, compliance requirements might dictate that you store data at even greater distances. With S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR), you can replicate data between distant AWS Regions to help satisfy these requirements. CRR enables automatic, asynchronous copying of objects across buckets in different AWS Regions. For more information, see Replicating objects.

Note

CRR requires both the source and destination S3 buckets to have versioning enabled.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-replication-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Object Lock
countermeasure.desc:
With S3 Object Lock, you can store objects by using a "Write Once Read Many" (WORM) model. S3 Object Lock can help prevent accidental or inappropriate deletion of data. For example, you can use S3 Object Lock to help protect your AWS CloudTrail logs.

For more information, see Using S3 Object Lock.

countermeasure.name: Disable access control lists (ACLs) and use bucket policies to manage permissions
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Object Ownership is an Amazon S3 bucket-level setting that you can use to control ownership of objects uploaded to your bucket and to disable or enable ACLs. By default, Object Ownership is set to the Bucket owner enforced setting and all ACLs are disabled. When ACLs are disabled, the bucket owner owns all the objects in the bucket and manages access to data exclusively using access management policies.

A majority of modern use cases in Amazon S3 no longer require the use of access control lists (ACLs). We recommend that you disable ACLs, except in unusual circumstances where you must control access for each object individually. To disable ACLs and take ownership of every object in your bucket, apply the bucket owner enforced setting for S3 Object Ownership. When you disable ACLs, you can easily maintain a bucket with objects uploaded by different AWS accounts.

When ACLs are disabled access control for your data is based on policies, such as the following:

  • AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) user policies
  • S3 bucket policies
  • Virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint policies
  • AWS Organizations service control policies (SCPs)

Disabling ACLs simplifies permissions management and auditing. ACLs are disabled for new buckets by default. You can also disable ACLs for existing buckets. If you have an existing bucket that already has objects in it, after you disable ACLs, the object and bucket ACLs are no longer part of the access-evaluation process. Instead, access is granted or denied on the basis of policies.

Before you disable ACLs, make sure that you do the following:

  • Review your bucket policy to ensure that it covers all the ways that you intend to grant access to your bucket outside of your account.
  • Reset your bucket ACL to the default (full control to the bucket owner).

After you disable ACLs, the following behaviors occur:

  • Your bucket accepts only PUT requests that do not specify an ACL or PUT requests with bucket owner full control ACLs. These ACLs include the bucket-owner-full-control canned ACL or equivalent forms of this ACL that are expressed in XML.
  • Existing applications that support bucket owner full control ACLs see no impact.
  • PUT requests that contain other ACLs (for example, custom grants to certain AWS accounts) fail and return an HTTP status code 400 (Bad Request) with the error code AccessControlListNotSupported.

For more information, see Controlling ownership of objects and disabling ACLs for your bucket.

countermeasure.name: Discover sensitive data by using Amazon Macie
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon Macie is a security service that discovers sensitive data by using machine learning and pattern matching. Macie provides visibility into data security risks, and enables automated protection against those risks. With Macie, you can automate the discovery and reporting of sensitive data in your Amazon S3 data estate to gain a better understanding of the data that your organization stores in S3.

To detect sensitive data with Macie, you can use built-in criteria and techniques that are designed to detect a large and growing list of sensitive data types for many countries and regions. These sensitive data types include multiple types of personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and credentials data. You can also use custom criteria that you defineregular expressions that define text patterns to match and, optionally, character sequences and proximity rules that refine the results.

If Macie detects sensitive data in an S3 object, Macie generates a security finding to notify you. This finding provides information about the affected object, the types and number of occurrences of the sensitive data that Macie found, and additional details to help you investigate the affected S3 bucket and object. For more information, see the Amazon Macie User Guide.

countermeasure.desc:
Server access logging provides detailed records of the requests that are made to a bucket. Server access logs can assist you in security and access audits, help you learn about your customer base, and understand your Amazon S3 bill. For instructions on enabling server access logging, see Logging requests with server access logging.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-logging-enabled AWS Config managed rule.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Several of the best practices listed in this topic suggest creating AWS Config rules. AWS Config helps you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. AWS Config monitors resource configurations so that you can evaluate the recorded configurations against the desired secure configurations. With AWS Config, you can do the following:

  • Review changes in configurations and relationships between AWS resources
  • Investigate detailed resource-configuration histories
  • Determine your overall compliance against the configurations specified in your internal guidelines

Using AWS Config can help you simplify compliance auditing, security analysis, change management, and operational troubleshooting. For more information, see Setting Up AWS Config with the Console in the AWS Config Developer Guide. When specifying the resource types to record, ensure that you include Amazon S3 resources.

Important

AWS Config managed rules only supports general purpose buckets when evaluating Amazon S3 resources. AWS Config doesnt record configuration changes for directory buckets. For more information, see AWS Config Managed Rules and List of AWS Config Managed Rules in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

For an example of how to use AWS Config, see How to Use AWS Config to Monitor for and Respond to Amazon S3 Buckets Allowing Public Access on the AWS Security Blog.

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 versioning
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Versioning is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. You can use versioning to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your bucket. With versioning, you can easily recover from both unintended user actions and application failures.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-versioning-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

For more information, see Using versioning in S3 buckets.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption of data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
You can use HTTPS (TLS) to help prevent potential attackers from eavesdropping on or manipulating network traffic by using person-in-the-middle or similar attacks. We recommend allowing only encrypted connections over HTTPS (TLS) by using the aws:SecureTransport condition in your Amazon S3 bucket policies.

Important

We recommend that your application not pin Amazon S3 TLS certificates as AWS doesnt support pinning of publicly-trusted certificates. S3 automatically renews certificates and renewal can happen any time before certificate expiry. Renewing a certificate generates a new public-private key pair. If youve pinned an S3 certificate which has been recently renewed with a new public key, you wont be able to connect to S3 until your application uses the new certificate.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-ssl-requests-only managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Ensure that your Amazon S3 buckets use the correct policies and are not publicly accessible
countermeasure.desc:
Unless you explicitly require anyone on the internet to be able to read or write to your S3 bucket, make sure that your S3 bucket is not public. The following are some of the steps that you can take to block public access:

  • Use S3 Block Public Access. With S3 Block Public Access, you can easily set up centralized controls to limit public access to your Amazon S3 resources. These centralized controls are enforced regardless of how the resources are created. For more information, see Blocking public access to your Amazon S3 storage.
  • Identify Amazon S3 bucket policies that allow a wildcard identity such as "Principal": "*" (which effectively means "anyone"). Also look for policies that allow a wildcard action "*" (which effectively allows the user to perform any action in the Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Similarly, look for Amazon S3 bucket access control lists (ACLs) that provide read, write, or full-access to "Everyone" or "Any authenticated AWS user."
  • Use the ListBuckets API operation to scan all of your Amazon S3 buckets. Then use GetBucketAcl, GetBucketWebsite, and GetBucketPolicy to determine whether each bucket has compliant access controls and a compliant configuration.
  • Use AWS Trusted Advisor to inspect your Amazon S3 implementation.
  • Consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited and s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited managed AWS Config Rules.

For more information, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

2.1.4 - Ensure that S3 is configured with 'Block Public Access' enabled
2.2.3 - Ensure that RDS instances are not publicly accessible

countermeasure.name: Identify and audit all of your Amazon S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Identification of your IT assets is a crucial aspect of governance and security. You need to have visibility of all your Amazon S3 resources to assess their security posture and take action on potential areas of weakness. To audit your resources, we recommend doing the following:

  • Use Tag Editor to identify and tag security-sensitive or audit-sensitive resources, then use those tags when you need to search for these resources. For more information, see Searching for Resources to Tag in the Tagging AWS Resources User Guide.
  • Use S3 Inventory to audit and report on the replication and encryption status of your objects for business, compliance, and regulatory needs. For more information, see Amazon S3 Inventory.
  • Create resource groups for your Amazon S3 resources. For more information, see What are resource groups? in the AWS Resource Groups User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Identify potential threats to your Amazon S3 buckets by using Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Amazon GuardDuty is a threat detection service that identifies potential threats to your accounts, containers, workloads, and the data within your AWS environment. By using machine learning (ML) models, and anomaly and threat detection capabilities, Amazon GuardDuty continuously monitors different data sources to identify and prioritize potential security risks and malicious activities in your environment. When you enable GuardDuty, it offers threat detection for foundational data sources that includes AWS CloudTrail management events, VPC flow logs, and DNS logs. To extend threat detection to data plane events in S3 buckets, you can enable the GuardDuty S3 Protection feature. This feature detects threats such as data exfiltration and suspicious access to S3 buckets via Tor nodes. GuardDuty also establishes a normal baseline pattern in your environment and when it identifies a potentially anomalous behavior, it provides contextual information to help you remediate the potentially compromised S3 bucket or AWS credentials. For more information, see GuardDuty.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
When granting permissions, you decide who is getting what permissions to which Amazon S3 resources. You enable specific actions that you want to allow on those resources. Therefore, we recommend that you grant only the permissions that are required to perform a task. Implementing least privilege access is fundamental in reducing security risk and the impact that could result from errors or malicious intent.

The following tools are available to implement least privilege access:

  • Policy actions for Amazon S3 and Permissions Boundaries for IAM Entities
  • How Amazon S3 works with IAM
  • Access control list (ACL) overview
  • Service Control Policies

For guidance on what to consider when choosing one or more of the preceding mechanisms, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Implement monitoring by using AWS monitoring tools
countermeasure.desc:
Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, security, availability, and performance of Amazon S3 and your AWS solutions. AWS provides several tools and services to help you monitor Amazon S3 and your other AWS services. For example, you can monitor Amazon CloudWatch metrics for Amazon S3, particularly the PutRequests, GetRequests, 4xxErrors, and DeleteRequests metrics. For more information, see Monitoring metrics with Amazon CloudWatch and Monitoring Amazon S3.

For a second example, see Example: Amazon S3 Bucket Activity. This example describes how to create a CloudWatch alarm that is triggered when an Amazon S3 API call is made to PUT or DELETE a bucket policy, a bucket lifecycle, or a bucket replication configuration, or to PUT a bucket ACL.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, a role, or an AWS service in Amazon S3. You can use information collected by CloudTrail to determine the following:

  • The request that was made to Amazon S3
  • The IP address from which the request was made
  • Who made the request
  • When the request was made
  • Additional details about the request

For example, you can identify CloudTrail entries for PUT actions that affect data access, in particular PutBucketAcl, PutObjectAcl, PutBucketPolicy, and PutBucketWebsite.

When you set up your AWS account, CloudTrail is enabled by default. You can view recent events in the CloudTrail console. To create an ongoing record of activity and events for your Amazon S3 buckets, you can create a trail in the CloudTrail console. For more information, see Logging data events in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

When you create a trail, you can configure CloudTrail to log data events. Data events are records of resource operations performed on or within a resource. In Amazon S3, data events record object-level API activity for individual buckets. CloudTrail supports a subset of Amazon S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject. For more information about how CloudTrail works with Amazon S3, see Logging Amazon S3 API calls using AWS CloudTrail. In the Amazon S3 console, you can also configure your S3 buckets to Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects.

AWS Config provides a managed rule (cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled) that you can use to confirm that at least one CloudTrail trail is logging data events for your S3 buckets. For more information, see cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for applications and AWS services that require Amazon S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
In order for applications running on Amazon EC2 or other AWS services to access Amazon S3 resources, they must include valid AWS credentials in their AWS API requests. We recommend not storing AWS credentials directly in the application or Amazon EC2 instance. These are long-term credentials that are not automatically rotated and could have a significant business impact if they are compromised.

Instead, use an IAM role to manage temporary credentials for applications or services that need to access Amazon S3. When you use a role, you don't have to distribute long-term credentials (such as a username and password or access keys) to an Amazon EC2 instance or AWS service, such as AWS Lambda. The role supplies temporary permissions that applications can use when they make calls to other AWS resources.

For more information, see the following topics in the IAM User Guide:

  • IAM Roles
  • Common Scenarios for Roles: Users, Applications, and Services

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Storage Lens
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Storage Lens is a cloud-storage analytics feature that you can use to gain organization-wide visibility into object-storage usage and activity. S3 Storage Lens also analyzes metrics to deliver contextual recommendations that you can use to optimize storage costs and apply best practices for protecting your data.

With S3 Storage Lens, you can use metrics to generate summary insights, such as finding out how much storage you have across your entire organization or which are the fastest-growing buckets and prefixes. You can also use S3 Storage Lens metrics to identify cost-optimization opportunities, implement data-protection and access-management best practices, and improve the performance of application workloads.

For example, you can identify buckets that don't have S3 Lifecycle rules to abort incomplete multipart uploads that are more than 7 days old. You can also identify buckets that aren't following data-protection best practices, such as using S3 Replication or S3 Versioning. For more information, see Understanding Amazon S3 Storage Lens.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized extraction of sensitive data from S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in Amazon S3 buckets may be extracted without proper oversight due to inadequate monitoring and insufficient access controls. This can lead to unauthorized data access, leaks, and breaches, compromising the integrity and confidentiality of the data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak access controls, lack of encryption, and insufficient logging and monitoring mechanisms, allowing undetected data exfiltration.

Impacts

Impacts include severe data breaches, loss of intellectual property, financial losses, legal consequences due to non-compliance with data protection regulations, and damage to an organization's reputation and customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An insider with access to an S3 bucket containing sensitive customer information downloads the data without being detected due to a lack of proper monitoring and oversight.
  2. An external attacker compromises an employee's AWS credentials and uses them to extract sensitive data from an S3 bucket, leading to a significant data breach and regulatory fines.
  3. Sensitive financial data stored in an S3 bucket is exfiltrated by an attacker exploiting overly permissive access controls, resulting in the exposure of confidential business information and competitive disadvantage.
  4. A lack of proper logging and alerting mechanisms allows an attacker to continuously extract small amounts of sensitive data over an extended period, going unnoticed until the breach is discovered during an audit.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The lack of adequate monitoring of Amazon S3 buckets can result in undetected data breaches or data loss. Without proper logging, alerting, and monitoring mechanisms, unauthorized access or malicious activities can go unnoticed, leading to severe security and compliance issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or non-existent monitoring systems, allowing attackers to access, modify, or extract data without detection.

Impacts

Impacts include significant data breaches, loss of sensitive and critical data, non-compliance with regulatory requirements, financial losses, and damage to the organization's reputation and customer trust. The inability to detect and respond to security incidents in a timely manner exacerbates these risks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to an S3 bucket and exfiltrates sensitive data over time. Due to inadequate monitoring, the breach remains undetected until the data is leaked or sold on the dark web, resulting in a major security incident.
  2. An insider with malicious intent deletes critical business data from an S3 bucket. Without proper monitoring and alerting mechanisms, the data loss is not identified until business operations are disrupted, causing significant financial and operational impacts.
  3. During a routine compliance audit, an organization discovers that an S3 bucket containing regulated data has been accessed by unauthorized users multiple times over the past year, leading to substantial fines and legal consequences.
  4. A lack of detailed logging and alerting allows an attacker to use compromised credentials to make unauthorized changes to an S3 bucket policy, granting themselves ongoing access and leading to a prolonged data breach that goes unnoticed for months.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure S3 bucket configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Amazon S3 buckets that are not properly secured may be accessible by unauthorized users. This can result from misconfigured permissions, lack of encryption, and absence of stringent access controls, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized data access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated bots scanning for misconfigured buckets. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or incorrect bucket policies, overly permissive access controls, and publicly accessible buckets without proper security measures.

Impacts

Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, loss of intellectual property, compliance violations, financial penalties, and damage to the organization's reputation. Misconfigured buckets can also lead to data manipulation or deletion, further compromising data integrity and availability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An S3 bucket containing confidential customer data is mistakenly configured with public read access, allowing anyone on the internet to access and download sensitive information, resulting in a significant data breach.
  2. During a routine security scan, it is discovered that several S3 buckets are accessible to unauthorized internal users due to misconfigured IAM policies, leading to unauthorized access and potential data leaks.
  3. An external attacker uses automated tools to identify and access an S3 bucket that has been inadvertently left publicly accessible. The attacker exfiltrates proprietary business information, causing financial and reputational damage to the company.
  4. A developer unintentionally grants write permissions to all authenticated AWS users on an S3 bucket, allowing unauthorized users to upload malicious content or delete critical data, leading to operational disruptions and potential legal issues.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

countermeasure.name: Configure AWS SDK retry logic and timeout settings for API resilience
countermeasure.desc: Configure the AWS SDK to use its built-in retry logic and timeout settings to handle transient network failures and ensure resilient API calls. Set appropriate retry strategies based on your application's needs, such as exponential backoff, and adjust timeout values to avoid premature failure. This ensures that your application remains stable and responsive during temporary service disruptions. Regularly test the configuration to optimize the balance between performance and resilience in your AWS environment.

reference.name: Retries and timeouts

countermeasure.name: Enable client-side encryption for secure data transmission to S3
countermeasure.desc: Use the AWS SDKs client-side encryption to ensure sensitive data is encrypted before it is transmitted to Amazon S3. This prevents data from being exposed during transit, even if intercepted. To implement this, configure the SDK's S3 encryption client in your application, enabling automatic encryption and decryption during upload and download. Regularly review and test encryption settings to ensure compliance with security standards and protect data confidentiality throughout its lifecycle in AWS.

reference.name: Protecting data by using client-side encryption

countermeasure.name: Utilize AWS SDK credential providers for secure credential management
countermeasure.desc: Leverage the AWS SDK's built-in credential providers, such as environment variables, shared credentials files, or IAM roles, to securely manage access credentials without hardcoding them in your application code. Ensure that the SDK is properly configured to fetch credentials from secure locations, minimizing the risk of accidental exposure. Regularly audit credential storage and access configurations to maintain security, and use IAM roles where applicable to grant fine-grained permissions to AWS resources.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Unreliable API calls due to network issues
threat.desc:
General threat description
AWS SDK-based applications may experience unreliable API calls due to transient network issues, resulting in failed or delayed interactions with AWS services.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Network outages, high latency, or service disruptions can interfere with API calls made through the SDK, causing interruptions or retries.

Impacts
Delayed responses, degraded performance, and potential service unavailability.

Example Attack Scenarios
An application using the AWS SDK faces frequent network timeouts, causing API calls to fail, leading to interruptions in data processing or delays in crucial service interactions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data exposure during transmission to S3
threat.desc:
General threat description
When data is transmitted to Amazon S3 without proper encryption, it can be intercepted or altered during transit, leading to potential exposure of sensitive information.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Man-in-the-middle (MitM) attackers can intercept unencrypted data during transmission, exploiting vulnerabilities in network communications.

Impacts
Data breaches, loss of confidentiality, and regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios
Sensitive data uploaded to S3 using the AWS SDK is intercepted by an attacker due to lack of encryption, exposing customer details or intellectual property during transit.

threat.name: Exposed credentials through insecure configuration
threat.desc:
General threat description
Storing AWS credentials insecurely in the AWS SDK configuration, such as hardcoding them in source code or misconfigured files, can lead to unauthorized access if exposed.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can gain access to credentials by inspecting source code repositories, environment variables, or compromised systems where credentials are improperly stored.

Impacts
Unauthorized access to AWS resources, data breaches, and potential service disruptions.

Example Attack Scenarios
AWS credentials are hardcoded in an application's source code, which is then uploaded to a public repository, allowing attackers to misuse the credentials to access AWS services.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

countermeasure.name: Regularly update AWS Managed Rules for AWS WAF
countermeasure.desc:
To maintain robust protection against new and emerging threats, it is critical to regularly update to the latest AWS Managed Rules for AWS WAF. AWS Managed Rules are pre-configured, managed rule groups created and maintained by AWS and AWS Marketplace Sellers. These rules are designed to protect applications from a variety of common threats and are regularly updated to address new vulnerabilities and risks.

Implementation Guidance for Cloud Engineers

  1. Open the AWS WAF console.
  2. In the navigation pane, click on Web ACLs, then select the Web ACL to which you wish to apply the managed rules.
  3. Under the Rules tab, click on Add managed rule group.
  4. Search for the latest AWS Managed Rules groups provided by AWS or trusted AWS Marketplace sellers in the rule group library.
  5. Select the appropriate rule groups based on your applications threat landscape and click Add rule group.
  6. Regularly review the AWS Managed Rules documentation and the AWS Managed Rule Groups section to stay informed about new updates and rule group changes.
  7. Periodically re-evaluate your Web ACLs to ensure they include the latest managed rules to guard against emerging threats.

For more detailed information and security guidelines, refer to the AWS WAF Developer Guide.

reference.name: CWE-693: CWE-693

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Use AWS WAF with AWS Shield Advanced to provide additional protections against DDoS attacks
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance protection against sophisticated Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks, it is recommended to integrate AWS WAF with AWS Shield Advanced. This integration provides advanced attack detection and mitigations specifically designed to protect your web applications from a multitude of threat vectors. Below are the steps to implement this control:

Steps to Implement the Control:

Enable AWS Shield Advanced: Ensure that AWS Shield Advanced is enabled on your AWS account. You can do this via the AWS Management Console by navigating to the AWS Shield Advanced Console and following the steps to enable the service on your desired resources.

Configure AWS WAF Web ACLs: Set up AWS WAF Web Access Control Lists (ACLs) to define rules that monitor and control web traffic. These rules help in filtering out common attack patterns and can be configured through the AWS WAF Developer Guide.

Associate AWS Shield Advanced with Web ACLs: Link the AWS Shield Advanced protections with the Web ACLs created in AWS WAF. This is done to ensure that the advanced DDoS detection and automatic mitigations are applied to the traffic monitored by your WAF rules.

Enable CloudWatch Alarms: Configure Amazon CloudWatch Alarms to monitor traffic patterns and trigger alerts during anomalous activities. This real-time alerting mechanism enables proactive monitoring and rapid response to potential attacks. Detailed steps for setting up CloudWatch Alarms can be found in the AWS WAF Developer Guide.

Review and Update Regularly: Periodically review and update the WAF rules and Shield Advanced configurations to address new attack vectors. Regular maintenance ensures that your defenses are up-to-date and capable of mitigating the latest threats.

References:

  • AWS WAF Developer Guide
  • Setting Up Amazon CloudWatch Alarms for AWS WAF

Implementing AWS WAF Bot Control is an effective way to manage and block bad bots, while allowing legitimate bot traffic. It provides predefined rules that identify and handle various categories of bots using machine learning and other detection techniques.

Guidance for Implementation:

  1. Access the AWS WAF Console:
  2. Configure Bot Control:
  3. Set Rule Actions:
  4. Tune Your Bot Control Rules:
  5. Monitor and Update:

For more details, refer to the AWS WAF Developer Guide - Bot Control.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Bot attacks
threat.desc:
General threat description
Bot attacks involve automated scripts that can scrape data, perform unauthorized actions, or conduct other malicious activities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious actors who design or deploy bots, often using compromised machines or cloud resources. They may target websites and web applications via HTTP/HTTPS requests to exploit vulnerabilities or harvest sensitive information.
Impacts
Impacts can range from decreased website performance and increased server load to data breaches, financial loss, and compromised user accounts. The integrity, availability, and confidentiality of web applications are at risk.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. A botnet is used to perform a large-scale credential stuffing attack against an online retailer, resulting in unauthorized access to user accounts. 2. Automated bots scrape pricing information from a competitor's website, disrupting their competitive edge and resulting in unfair market competition. 3. Bots are deployed to submit fraudulent transactions on an e-commerce site, causing financial losses and chargebacks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service

threat.name: HTTP flood attacks
threat.desc:
General threat description
HTTP Flood attacks occur when an attacker inundates a web server with a flood of HTTP requests, with the intention of overwhelming the system's capacity and causing performance degradation. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The attack is typically executed by using a distributed network of bots or compromised devices, often referred to as a botnet. These bots generate a high volume of seemingly legitimate HTTP requests, which can bypass traditional security measures. 
Impacts
The primary impact is a significant degradation in the performance of the web server, leading to slow response times or complete service outages. This can result in loss of revenue, damage to reputation, and increased operational costs as resources are allocated to mitigate the attack. 
Example Attack Scenarios
One example is an attacker using a botnet to flood an online retail website with a sharp increase in HTTP GET requests during a peak sale period, causing the site to become slow or unresponsive. Another example could be a political group targeting a governmental website with an HTTP POST request flood in an attempt to disrupt public services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1498 - Network Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Zero-day vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Zero-day vulnerabilities are security flaws in web applications that are not yet known to the software vendor or users, making them particularly dangerous as they can be exploited by attackers before any patch or fix is developed and applied.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers who discover these vulnerabilities can use a variety of vectors to exploit them, such as injecting malicious code, launching distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, or stealing sensitive data without detection.
Impacts
Successful exploitation of zero-day vulnerabilities can lead to unauthorized access to systems, data breaches, loss of sensitive information, service disruptions, and significant reputational damage to the affected organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies and exploits a zero-day vulnerability in a web application, gaining access to its backend database and exfiltrating user data, including personal and financial information, before the vulnerability is detected and patched by the developers.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

weakness.name: CWE-215
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-215: Insertion of Sensitive Information Into Debugging Code The product inserts sensitive information into debugging code, which could expose this information if the debugging code is not disabled in production. When debugging, it may be necessary to report detailed information to the programmer. However, if the debugging code is not disabled when the product is operating in a production environment, then this sensitive information may be exposed to attackers.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-664
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-664: Improper Control of a Resource Through its Lifetime The product does not maintain or incorrectly maintains control over a resource throughout its lifetime of creation, use, and release.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Configure CloudWatch logs to monitor image build activities
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of AWS EC2 Image Builder, configure AWS CloudWatch Logs to capture detailed logs of all image build activities. This enables continuous monitoring for unauthorized changes or anomalies in the image-building process.

Enable Logging for Image Builder Pipelines:

  • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the Image Builder service and select the pipelines you wish to monitor.
  • Enable CloudWatch logging for each pipeline to ensure that all build steps, configuration changes, and errors are logged.

Create a CloudWatch Log Group:

  • Create a dedicated CloudWatch Log Group for Image Builder logs to centralize log data for easier management and analysis.
  • Set appropriate retention policies for the log group based on your organizations data retention and compliance requirements.

Set Up Monitoring and Alerts:

  • Use CloudWatch Alarms to create alerts based on specific log patterns or events, such as build failures, unauthorized access attempts, or configuration changes.
  • Configure alerts to notify security teams via email, SMS, or integration with AWS SNS (Simple Notification Service) for real-time incident response.

Review Logs Regularly:

  • Regularly review CloudWatch logs for any unauthorized changes or anomalies in the build process.
  • Implement automated log analysis tools or scripts to detect patterns indicative of malicious activity or configuration drift.

reference.name: Monitor events and logs in Image Builder

countermeasure.name: Remove hard-coded sensitive data from build scripts and recipes
countermeasure.desc:
To prevent unauthorized access and data leakage, ensure that build scripts and recipes used in AWS EC2 Image Builder do not contain hard-coded sensitive data, such as credentials or API keys. Additionally, sanitize build outputs to remove any accidental inclusion of sensitive information.

Review and Clean Build Scripts:

  • Inspect all build scripts and recipes for any hard-coded sensitive data, such as usernames, passwords, API keys, or other confidential information.
  • Replace hard-coded sensitive information with environment variables or AWS Secrets Manager references to ensure sensitive data is not directly embedded in scripts.

Use AWS Secrets Manager or Parameter Store:

  • Store sensitive information securely using AWS Secrets Manager or AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store. Reference these securely stored secrets in your build scripts to avoid exposing them in plain text.
  • Set appropriate access permissions on secrets to ensure only authorized users and services can access them.

Sanitize Build Outputs:

  • Implement steps within your build process to sanitize outputs, such as removing temporary files, clearing environment variables, or scrubbing logs that might contain sensitive information.
  • Use automated scripts or tools to scan build outputs for any residual sensitive data before finalizing the image.

Implement Continuous Security Scanning:

  • Use security scanning tools to automatically check build scripts and outputs for hard-coded secrets or sensitive data. Integrate these scans into your CI/CD pipeline to ensure ongoing compliance.
  • Regularly update scanning tools and rules to detect new types of sensitive information.

reference.name: Security in Image Builder

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to Image Builder resources with IAM policies
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS EC2 Image Builder, configure AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies to restrict access to Image Builder resources, ensuring that only authorized users or roles have the necessary permissions.

Define Least Privilege IAM Policies:

  • Create IAM policies that adhere to the principle of least privilege, granting only the minimum permissions required for users or roles to perform their specific tasks in Image Builder.
  • For example, create separate policies for users who only need read access to image pipelines versus those who require full control to create or modify resources.

Assign IAM Roles to Image Builder Resources:

  • Use IAM roles to manage permissions for EC2 instances, pipelines, and other resources used by Image Builder. Assign these roles to resources in a way that limits access to only what is necessary for the build process.
  • Ensure that roles assigned to Image Builder resources are configured with trust policies to prevent unauthorized use.

Regularly Review and Update IAM Policies:

  • Periodically review IAM policies and access permissions to ensure they are up-to-date and reflect current security requirements. Remove or update policies that grant excessive permissions.
  • Conduct regular audits to identify and revoke any unused or overly permissive roles and access keys.

Monitor and Log IAM Access:

  • Enable AWS CloudTrail to log all IAM-related activities and monitor access to Image Builder resources. Set up alerts for any unauthorized access attempts or policy changes.
  • Use AWS IAM Access Analyzer to identify resources that are accessible from outside your AWS account and tighten permissions as needed.

reference.name: Image Builder identity-based policies

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Store built images in encrypted and secure storage
countermeasure.desc:
To protect the integrity and confidentiality of AWS EC2 Image Builder outputs, ensure that all built images are stored in encrypted Amazon S3 buckets or other secure, access-controlled storage options.

Enable Encryption for S3 Buckets:

  • When storing built images in Amazon S3, enable server-side encryption (SSE) using AWS KMS-managed keys (SSE-KMS) or S3-managed keys (SSE-S3) to encrypt images at rest.
  • Configure S3 bucket policies to enforce encryption on all uploads, ensuring no unencrypted images are stored.

Implement Strict Access Controls:

  • Use AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies and S3 bucket policies to restrict access to the buckets storing built images. Grant permissions only to specific users or roles that need access, following the principle of least privilege.
  • Configure S3 Access Control Lists (ACLs) to ensure that no public access is allowed unless explicitly required for specific use cases.

Regularly Audit Storage Permissions:

  • Set up regular audits of S3 bucket permissions and access logs using AWS CloudTrail to ensure that access controls are properly configured and no unauthorized access has occurred.
  • Use AWS Config rules to continuously monitor the S3 bucket settings and receive alerts for any deviations from the security baseline.

Use Additional Secure Storage Options:

  • If storing images outside of S3, ensure that the storage service or infrastructure used supports encryption at rest and robust access controls.
  • Implement similar security controls, such as encryption, access control, and logging, to maintain the security of images stored in alternative storage solutions.

reference.name: Security in Image Builder
