countermeasure.name: Use trusted and verified base images for image builds
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security and integrity of images created with AWS EC2 Image Builder, always use trusted and verified base images from reputable sources, such as AWS Marketplace or internally vetted images.

Select Verified Base Images:

  • Choose base images from trusted sources like AWS Marketplace, which provides verified images that are regularly updated and maintained to ensure security and compliance.
  • When using internally vetted images, ensure they have been thoroughly tested and approved by your organizations security team.

Establish a Base Image Approval Process:

  • Implement a formal process for approving base images before they are used in the build process. This process should include security checks, vulnerability scans, and validation against your organizations security standards.
  • Maintain a list of approved base images and update it regularly to ensure that only secure and compliant images are used.

Regularly Update Base Images:

  • Ensure that base images are regularly updated with the latest security patches and updates. Set up automated checks or notifications to stay informed of new image versions or patches available from your trusted sources.
  • Replace outdated or unsupported images in your build pipelines with their updated, secure versions.

Monitor for Image Changes or Compromises:

  • Use AWS services like AWS Config and AWS CloudTrail to monitor for any unauthorized changes or modifications to your base images. Set up alerts for unexpected modifications or access attempts.
  • Regularly audit your image repository to detect any signs of compromise or unauthorized images being used.

reference.name: Security in Image Builder

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Image Builder components
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Unauthorized access to AWS EC2 Image Builder components, such as pipelines, recipes, and distribution settings, can allow attackers to modify images, insert malicious code, or disrupt the image creation process, compromising the security of deployed instances.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, compromised accounts.
  • Vectors:
    • Weak or misconfigured IAM policies granting broad access.
    • Compromised credentials or roles with Image Builder access.
    • Inadequate access controls on AWS resources.

Impacts:

  • Security Breach: Compromised images containing vulnerabilities or malware.
  • Operational Disruption: Disruption of image-building pipelines and deployment processes.
  • Data Leakage: Exposure of sensitive information within image configurations.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust due to deployment of insecure instances.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Compromised IAM Role: An attacker uses a compromised IAM role with broad permissions to insert a backdoor into an image recipe, leading to compromised instances.
  • Misconfigured Public Access: Public access to pipelines is mistakenly allowed, enabling a malicious insider to use outdated base images with known vulnerabilities.
  • Insider Manipulation: An employee alters distribution settings to leak images to unauthorized regions or accounts, risking exposure of proprietary data.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data in built images
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Exposure of sensitive data in built images occurs when credentials, API keys, or other sensitive information are unintentionally included in images during the AWS EC2 Image Builder process. This can lead to unauthorized access and misuse of the exposed data, compromising security and privacy.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, unauthorized users.
  • Vectors:
    • Hard-coded sensitive data within image build scripts or configuration files.
    • Insufficient sanitization of build artifacts or logs containing sensitive information.
    • Use of unprotected environment variables or files during the build process.

Impacts:

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to credentials or sensitive information, potentially leading to further breaches.
  • Service Compromise: Exposure of API keys or credentials could allow attackers to access or manipulate AWS resources.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaches of regulatory requirements due to inadequate protection of sensitive data.
  • Financial Loss: Potential costs associated with incident response, fines, and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Hard-Coded Credentials in Build Scripts: An engineer includes database credentials in a build script for convenience. These credentials are inadvertently baked into the final image, allowing attackers to access the database when the image is deployed.
  • Unprotected Environment Variables: Sensitive information is stored in environment variables used during the image-building process. If these variables are not properly sanitized, they could be exposed in the built image or build logs.
  • Insufficient Data Sanitization: An outdated build script inadvertently copies a configuration file containing sensitive customer data into the final image, resulting in data exposure when the image is deployed.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure storage of built images
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

Insecure storage of built images in AWS EC2 Image Builder can expose images to unauthorized access, modification, or tampering. If built images are stored in unsecured locations, such as unencrypted S3 buckets or improperly configured storage services, they can be accessed by malicious actors, potentially leading to the deployment of compromised or malicious instances.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Vectors:
    • Storing built images in unencrypted S3 buckets or other storage locations.
    • Misconfigured bucket policies or ACLs that allow public or unauthorized access.
    • Lack of access controls, allowing unrestricted access to image storage locations.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized Access: Malicious actors can access or download built images, potentially exposing sensitive configurations or embedded data.
  • Image Tampering: Attackers may modify stored images to include malicious code or backdoors.
  • Compliance Violations: Storing sensitive images without proper encryption or access controls may breach regulatory requirements.
  • Deployment of Compromised Instances: Deployment of tampered or malicious images could compromise application and infrastructure security.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Unencrypted Image Storage: Built images are stored in an S3 bucket without encryption. A cybercriminal gains access to the bucket and downloads the images, analyzing them for vulnerabilities or sensitive information.
  • Publicly Accessible S3 Bucket: An administrator misconfigures an S3 bucket policy, making it publicly accessible. An attacker discovers the misconfiguration and modifies the images to include a backdoor before they are deployed.
  • Improper Access Controls: An insider with excessive access permissions deletes critical images or replaces them with unauthorized versions, leading to deployment issues and potential security breaches.

threat.name: Lack of monitoring and logging for image builds
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

"Lack of Monitoring and Logging for Image Builds" refers to the absence of adequate monitoring and logging mechanisms for AWS EC2 Image Builder processes. Without detailed logging and monitoring, unauthorized changes, malicious activities, or failures in the image-building pipeline may go undetected, compromising the security and integrity of the resulting images.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, negligent administrators.
  • Vectors:
    • Lack of detailed logs capturing the build process, changes, or errors.
    • Insufficient monitoring of build pipeline activities, leading to undetected unauthorized modifications.
    • No alerts or notifications set up for failed or suspicious build activities.

Impacts:

  • Undetected Security Incidents: Malicious changes or unauthorized access may go unnoticed, resulting in compromised images.
  • Operational Inefficiencies: Failures or issues in the build process may not be identified promptly, delaying deployments and updates.
  • Compliance Violations: Failing to log and monitor critical activities can lead to non-compliance with security policies and regulations.
  • Image Integrity Compromise: Lack of monitoring may allow corrupted or compromised images to be deployed, posing risks to application and infrastructure security.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Undetected Malicious Changes: An insider with access to Image Builder components alters a build script to include malicious code. Without detailed logging or monitoring, this unauthorized change goes unnoticed, resulting in compromised images being deployed.
  • Missed Build Failures: An external attacker exploits a vulnerability in a base image, causing the build process to fail intermittently. Due to a lack of monitoring, these failures are not detected, delaying response and remediation efforts.
  • Unauthorized Access Remains Unnoticed: A compromised IAM user accesses Image Builder components and makes unauthorized changes to the distribution settings. Without proper logging and monitoring, the breach remains undetected until the compromised images are deployed.

threat.name: Use of untrusted source images
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:

The "Use of Untrusted Source Images" threat occurs when AWS EC2 Image Builder uses base images that are not verified or come from unreliable sources. This can introduce vulnerabilities, malware, or backdoors into the built images, posing significant security risks to the entire environment where these images are deployed.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Vectors:
    • Utilizing base images from unverified or third-party repositories with unknown security practices.
    • Incorporating images that have been compromised or contain outdated software with known vulnerabilities.
    • Lack of proper vetting processes for sourcing and updating base images.

Impacts:

  • Security Compromise: Deployment of images built from untrusted sources may introduce malware or unauthorized access points.
  • Data Breach: Compromised images could allow attackers to exfiltrate sensitive data or access other resources.
  • Operational Disruption: Vulnerable or malicious images could lead to service outages, degraded performance, or loss of control over systems.
  • Compliance Violations: Using unverified images could lead to non-compliance with regulatory requirements or internal security policies.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • Deployment of Compromised Image: A base image from an unverified third-party source is used in the build process. The image contains hidden malware that activates upon deployment, providing attackers with unauthorized access to the network.
  • Outdated Image with Known Vulnerabilities: An image is sourced from an external repository without verification and contains outdated software with known vulnerabilities. Attackers exploit these vulnerabilities to gain access to critical systems after the image is deployed.
  • Malicious Insider Incident: An insider with access to the Image Builder pipeline replaces a trusted base image with a tampered version from an untrusted source. This modified image includes a backdoor that is later used to gain unauthorized access to the deployed environment.

countermeasure.name: Enable comprehensive data access logging
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS Cost Management, enable logging for all data access events to monitor and audit data usage and detect any unauthorized access. Implement AWS CloudTrail to capture and review access logs, ensuring all actions taken by users, roles, or AWS services are recorded.

Implementation Steps:

Enable CloudTrail: Set up AWS CloudTrail for your AWS account to capture API calls and access events related to AWS Cost Management.

Configure Logging: Ensure CloudTrail is configured to log all data access events, including read and write actions.

Store Logs Securely: Save the logs in a secure S3 bucket with proper access controls to prevent unauthorized access to log data.

Regular Review: Schedule regular reviews of CloudTrail logs to detect and investigate any unauthorized or suspicious access events.

Set Up Alerts: Configure CloudWatch Alarms to alert security teams of any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts detected in the logs.

countermeasure.name: Enforce secure data transfer methods
countermeasure.desc:
To protect data in transit within AWS Cost Management, ensure that all data transfers use secure methods such as HTTPS or SFTP. Regularly update configurations to enforce secure transfer protocols, preventing unauthorized access and data interception.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Secure Transfers: Set up data transfers using HTTPS for web-based communications and SFTP for file transfers.

Regular Updates: Periodically review and update transfer configurations to ensure they adhere to the latest security standards and protocols.

Audit Transfer Protocols: Conduct regular audits to verify that all data transfers use secure methods and no insecure protocols are in use.

User Training: Educate users on the importance of using secure transfer methods and how to configure them properly.

countermeasure.name: Implement data versioning for integrity
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS Cost Management data, implement data versioning to keep track of changes and ensure data integrity. Versioning helps identify unauthorized modifications and allows restoration of previous versions, maintaining accurate and reliable data sets.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Versioning: Configure data repositories (e.g., Amazon S3) to support versioning for all relevant data sets.

Automate Version Management: Use scripts or AWS Lambda to manage data versions, ensuring all changes are versioned and stored appropriately.

Monitor Changes: Regularly review version histories to detect and analyze changes, identifying any unauthorized modifications.

Audit and Review: Conduct periodic audits to ensure compliance with versioning policies and data integrity requirements.

countermeasure.name: Prohibit sensitive information in tags
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS Cost Management, ensure that tags do not contain sensitive information to prevent exposure through tag-based access. Implement regular audits to verify compliance with this policy.

Implementation Steps:

Define Tagging Policies: Establish and communicate policies that prohibit the inclusion of sensitive information in tags.

Automate Tag Validation: Use automated scripts or AWS Config rules to scan tags for sensitive data and enforce compliance with tagging policies.

Manual Audits: Regularly conduct manual audits to ensure tags do not contain sensitive information and adhere to established policies.

User Training: Educate employees on the risks and policies regarding sensitive information in tags.

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to Cost Management data sets
countermeasure.desc:
To secure AWS Cost Management data sets, limit access to authorized users by configuring appropriate access controls and regularly reviewing permissions. This ensures that only users with the necessary permissions can access sensitive financial data.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Access Controls: Set up access controls using AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) to restrict access to specific users and roles.

Use Least Privilege Principle: Assign permissions based on the principle of least privilege, granting users only the access they need to perform their job functions.

Regularly Review Permissions: Conduct regular reviews of user permissions and access logs to ensure compliance and adjust as necessary.

Monitor Access: Implement monitoring tools to track and log access to cost management data, ensuring unauthorized access attempts are detected and addressed.

threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access to AWS Cost Management data involves individuals gaining access to sensitive financial information without proper authorization. This can lead to data breaches, misuse of financial data, and compromised data integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Users: Employees with excessive or improperly managed permissions.
  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting vulnerabilities or using compromised credentials.
  • Misconfigurations: Incorrectly configured access controls and permissions.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive financial information.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaches of regulatory requirements and data protection laws.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust and credibility due to unauthorized data access.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Credentials: An attacker uses stolen credentials to access sensitive financial data in AWS Cost Management.
  2. Insider Threat: An employee with excessive permissions accesses and exfiltrates confidential financial data.
  3. Access Control Misconfiguration: Incorrect access controls allow broader access than intended, leading to unauthorized data retrieval.

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data in tags
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Exposure of sensitive data in tags within AWS Cost Management can lead to unauthorized access and data breaches. Tags, often used for resource organization, should not contain confidential information as they may be visible in logs and billing reports.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Users: Employees unintentionally or intentionally adding sensitive data to tags.
  • External Attackers: Hackers gaining access through compromised accounts or misconfigurations.
  • Automated Tools: Scripts that expose or misuse tag data.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information.
  • Compliance Violations: Exposure leading to non-compliance with data protection regulations.
  • Operational Risks: Misuse of exposed data disrupting operations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unintended Exposure: An employee includes customer PII in tags for easier identification, leading to exposure in billing reports accessible by various teams.
  2. Log Exposure: Tags containing sensitive data are included in logs, which are then accessed by unauthorized users or shared externally.
  3. Misconfigured Access: Tags with sensitive information are used in environments with misconfigured access controls, leading to broader exposure than intended.

threat.name: Insecure data transfers
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insecure data transfers in AWS Cost Management involve transmitting data over unencrypted or poorly secured channels, making it vulnerable to interception and unauthorized access. Ensuring secure data transfer methods is crucial to protect sensitive financial information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Intercepting data via network vulnerabilities or man-in-the-middle attacks.
  • Internal Threats: Employees transmitting data using insecure methods.
  • Misconfigurations: Incorrectly configured transfer protocols exposing data in transit.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive data during transmission.
  • Integrity Loss: Data can be tampered with during insecure transfers.
  • Compliance Issues: Failure to secure data in transit can lead to regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Man-in-the-Middle Attack: An attacker intercepts data being transferred over an unsecured HTTP connection, gaining access to sensitive financial information.
  2. Insecure API Usage: An employee uses an API endpoint that doesnt enforce HTTPS, exposing data to interception.
  3. Misconfigured SFTP: Data transferred using misconfigured SFTP without proper encryption settings, leading to potential data leakage.

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring of data access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insufficient monitoring of data access in AWS Cost Management can result in unauthorized activities going undetected, increasing the risk of data breaches and misuse of sensitive information. Effective monitoring is essential for identifying and responding to suspicious activities promptly.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Users: Employees accessing data without proper oversight or logging.
  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting the lack of monitoring to access and manipulate data undetected.
  • Misconfigurations: Incorrectly set up logging and monitoring tools leading to gaps in visibility.

Impacts

  • Undetected Data Breaches: Unauthorized access and data exfiltration without timely detection.
  • Non-Compliance: Failure to meet regulatory requirements for data access monitoring.
  • Operational Risks: Inability to quickly respond to and mitigate security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Internal Data Theft: An employee accesses and exfiltrates sensitive data without triggering any alerts due to insufficient monitoring.
  2. External Compromise: An attacker gains access through a compromised account and continues to extract information over time without being detected.
  3. Configuration Error: A misconfiguration in the monitoring setup leads to critical access logs not being captured, allowing unauthorized activities to go unnoticed.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Data tampering
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data tampering in AWS Cost Management involves unauthorized alteration of cost management data, compromising the integrity and reliability of financial reports and forecasts. Such actions can lead to inaccurate cost analysis and decision-making.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Users: Insiders with access to modify data.
  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting system vulnerabilities to alter data.
  • Automated Tools: Malicious scripts or malware modifying data without authorization.

Impacts

  • Data Integrity: Compromised accuracy and trustworthiness of financial data.
  • Operational Disruption: Incorrect data leading to faulty decisions and operational inefficiencies.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of credibility and trust due to tampered financial reports.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Insider Manipulation: An employee alters financial data to hide fraudulent activities, resulting in misleading financial reports.
  2. External Exploit: An attacker breaches the system and modifies cost data, causing inaccuracies in cost forecasting.
  3. Malware Attack: A malware script infiltrates the system, automatically altering data values and disrupting normal operations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1493 - Transmitted Data Manipulation

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-89
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

weakness.name: CWE-914
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-914: Improper Control of Dynamically-Identified Variables The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-identified variables. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to access arbitrary variables that are specified by an input string. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can modify unintended variables that have security implications.

countermeasure.name: Enforce secure file permissions on database files
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update strict file system permissions on Other Data Store database files to ensure that only authorized users and processes can access or modify them. This control minimizes the risk of unauthorized data tampering or exposure by configuring OS-level permissions (e.g., using tools like chmod and chown on Unix/Linux systems) or centralized configuration management solutions. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate these practices into the deployment and maintenance processes, and perform periodic audits to verify compliance with security best practices.

References:

  • OWASP Secure Coding Practices - Access Control

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS encryption for all connections
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update TLS encryption for all connections to the Other Data Store to secure data in transit. This control ensures that every client-to-database and inter-node communication is encrypted using robust TLS protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2/1.3), thereby mitigating risks such as eavesdropping and man-in-the-middle attacks. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate TLS configuration into the deployment process and enforce these settings via centralized management tools, ensuring that all data exchanged across the network remains confidential and tamper-proof.

Implementation Steps:

Enable TLS Encryption:
Configure the Other Data Store to require TLS for all incoming and outgoing connections by setting the appropriate parameters in the configuration files.

Configure Secure Cipher Suites:
Enforce the use of modern TLS versions (TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3) and disable deprecated protocols and weak cipher suites to maintain strong encryption standards.

Manage Certificates Securely:
Utilize a centralized certificate management system to issue, renew, and revoke TLS certificates, ensuring that all certificates are valid and up-to-date.

Monitor and Audit TLS Usage:
Regularly review connection logs and perform security audits to verify that TLS encryption is properly enforced across all connections and to identify any potential misconfigurations.

References:

  • OWASP Transport Layer Protection Cheat Sheet

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Harden configuration and restrict network access
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that your Other Data Store is configured securely by removing unnecessary services and features while enforcing strict network access policies. Developers and DevOps engineers should incorporate configuration hardening into the deployment process and implement robust network access controls using firewalls, security groups, or network ACLs. This minimizes the attack surface, prevents unauthorized access, and protects the system from potential exploitation of misconfigurations.

Implementation Steps:

Harden Configuration:

  • Disable Unnecessary Services and Features: Review and disable default or unnecessary functionalities that could expose vulnerabilities.
  • Apply Regular Updates and Patches: Keep the data store software and underlying operating system updated with the latest security patches.
  • Enforce Secure Configuration Settings: Replace default credentials and adjust configurations to follow security best practices.

Restrict Network Access:

  • Define and Enforce Firewall Rules: Configure firewall rules, security groups, or network ACLs to allow traffic only from authorized IP addresses and to only the necessary ports.
  • Network Segmentation: Isolate the Other Data Store within a dedicated subnet to limit exposure and control the traffic flow.
  • Centralized Access Management: Utilize centralized tools for monitoring and managing network access rules to ensure consistency across environments.

Monitor and Audit:

  • Regular Security Audits: Continuously monitor and audit both configuration settings and network access logs to detect any anomalies or unauthorized changes.
  • Automated Configuration Scanning: Integrate automated tools that can verify compliance with the secure configuration and network restrictions, alerting you to any deviations.

References:

  • NIST Special Publication 800-123: Guide to General Server Security

countermeasure.name: Implement rate limiting and resource throttling
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that your Other Data Store is safeguarded against denial-of-service (DoS) attacks and resource exhaustion by enforcing rate limiting and resource throttling policies. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate these mechanisms into both the application and network layers to manage and mitigate traffic surges, ensuring consistent performance and availability for legitimate users.

Implementation Steps:

Rate Limiting:

  • Configure Request Limits: Set up mechanisms (e.g., token bucket or leaky bucket algorithms) to limit the number of requests per second from each client or IP address.
  • Implement at Multiple Layers: Apply rate limiting at both the application layer (within the data store or via an API gateway) and at the network layer (using firewalls or load balancers) to provide a layered defense.

Resource Throttling:

  • Define Resource Quotas: Establish thresholds for critical resources such as CPU, memory, and database connections to prevent any single client or process from consuming excessive resources.
  • Enforce Quotas and Pools: Use resource pools or quotas to ensure fair allocation of resources and to isolate workloads during peak usage periods.

Monitoring and Alerting:

  • Track Traffic and Resource Usage: Continuously monitor traffic patterns and system resource utilization to identify anomalies or potential abuse.
  • Set Automated Alerts: Configure alerts to notify the operations team if traffic exceeds defined thresholds or if resource usage approaches critical levels.

References:

  • OWASP API Security: Rate Limiting

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Implement secure backup procedures with encryption and access controls
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that all backup processes for your Other Data Store are secure, with data encrypted both in transit and at rest, and accessible only to authorized personnel. Developers and DevOps engineers should incorporate secure backup procedures into the deployment and maintenance workflows to mitigate risks related to data loss, unauthorized access, and potential data breaches.

Implementation Steps:

Automated and Regular Backups:

  • Schedule Backups: Configure automated backup jobs to run at regular intervals, ensuring that data is consistently backed up without manual intervention.
  • Verify Backup Integrity: Regularly test backup integrity and perform restore drills to confirm that data can be reliably recovered.

Encryption of Backup Data:

  • Encrypt Data at Rest: Use strong encryption standards (e.g., AES-256) to secure backup files stored on disk or in cloud storage.
  • Encrypt Data in Transit: Ensure that backup data is encrypted during transmission using secure protocols (e.g., TLS) to prevent interception.

Access Controls:

  • Restrict Access: Implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) to limit backup access to authorized personnel only.
  • Audit Logging: Maintain logs of all backup operations and access attempts to provide traceability and assist in identifying potential security incidents.

Secure Storage Environment:

  • Isolated Storage: Store backup files in a segregated environment that is separate from the production network to reduce exposure.
  • Redundancy and Geographic Distribution: Ensure backups are stored across multiple secure locations to protect against localized failures or disasters.

Centralized Management:

  • Use Management Tools: Integrate backup operations with centralized management systems to enforce encryption policies and access controls consistently across all environments.
  • Continuous Monitoring: Regularly review and audit backup configurations and access logs to identify and remediate potential security gaps.

References:

  • NIST Special Publication 800-171: Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information in Nonfederal Systems

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Implement strong authentication and role-based access control
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that only authorized users can access the Other Data Store through the use of strong authentication mechanisms, and that access rights are limited based on defined roles. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate multi-factor authentication (MFA) and a robust role-based access control (RBAC) system into the deployment process to minimize the risk of unauthorized access and privilege escalation.

Implementation Steps:

Strong Authentication:

  • Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Require users to verify their identities using at least two factors (e.g., password plus a one-time code or hardware token) before granting access.
  • Adopt Secure Authentication Protocols: Use industry-standard protocols (e.g., OAuth 2.0, SAML, or OpenID Connect) to manage authentication securely.
  • Enforce Password Policies: Require strong, complex passwords and mandate periodic password changes to reduce the risk of compromised credentials.

Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

  • Define User Roles and Permissions: Identify distinct roles (e.g., administrator, developer, auditor) and assign permissions based on the principle of least privilege, ensuring that each role has only the access necessary to perform its functions.
  • Centralize Identity and Access Management (IAM): Integrate with a centralized IAM solution to manage user roles and access policies consistently across environments.
  • Automate Role Assignments: Utilize automation tools to enforce RBAC policies during the provisioning and deprovisioning of user accounts, reducing the risk of human error.

Monitoring and Auditing:

  • Log Authentication Events: Capture detailed logs for all authentication and access control events to monitor for suspicious activities or potential breaches.
  • Regularly Review Permissions: Periodically audit and adjust role assignments and permissions to ensure ongoing compliance with the principle of least privilege.
  • Integrate with SIEM Tools: Use Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) solutions to correlate logs and detect anomalies in authentication patterns.

References:

  • OWASP Authentication Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Regularly update the data store to the latest secure version
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that your Other Data Store remains secure by keeping its software and underlying components up-to-date with the latest security patches and version releases. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate a robust update management process into their deployment workflows to minimize vulnerabilities and mitigate the risk of exploitation.

Implementation Steps:

Establish an Update Management Process:

  • Monitor Vendor Announcements: Subscribe to security advisories and release notes from the data store vendor to stay informed about new versions and patches.
  • Schedule Regular Updates: Define a routine maintenance schedule that includes regular checks and timely updates to the latest secure versions.
  • Test Updates in a Staging Environment: Validate updates in a non-production environment to ensure compatibility and to prevent disruptions during deployment.

Automate Update Procedures:

  • Use Configuration Management Tools: Leverage tools like Ansible, Puppet, or Chef to automate the update process, ensuring consistency and reducing manual errors.
  • Implement Continuous Monitoring: Integrate monitoring solutions that can detect outdated components and trigger automated update workflows.

Enforce Secure Update Policies:

  • Establish Rollback Mechanisms: Prepare contingency plans and maintain version backups to facilitate rollback in case an update causes unexpected issues.
  • Audit and Log Update Activities: Maintain comprehensive logs of update operations for auditing purposes and to track compliance with security policies.
  • Verify Integrity Post-Update: Perform post-update security assessments to confirm that the data store operates securely after applying new patches or versions.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-40 Revision 3: Guide to Enterprise Patch Management Technologies

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Use parameterized queries and validate inputs
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that your Other Data Store is protected against SQL injection and other injection attacks by using parameterized queries and robust input validation. Developers and DevOps engineers should incorporate these techniques into the application development and database interaction processes to prevent attackers from injecting malicious code and compromising data integrity.

Implementation Steps:

Use Parameterized Queries:

  • Adopt Prepared Statements: Always use prepared statements with parameterized queries when interacting with the database to separate code from data.
  • Avoid Dynamic Query Construction: Refrain from concatenating user inputs into SQL queries. Instead, pass user inputs as parameters to prepared statements to ensure they are treated as data rather than executable code.
  • Leverage ORM Frameworks: Consider using Object-Relational Mapping (ORM) frameworks that inherently use parameterized queries and provide an additional layer of abstraction.

Validate Inputs:

  • Implement Input Sanitization: Validate and sanitize all user inputs on both the client and server sides to ensure they conform to the expected formats, lengths, and types.
  • Enforce Whitelisting: Where possible, use whitelisting techniques to allow only known-good values, reducing the likelihood of malicious input.
  • Validate Data Types: Ensure that user inputs match the expected data types (e.g., numeric, string, date) before processing or storing them in the database.

Testing and Monitoring:

  • Conduct Regular Code Reviews: Regularly review code for potential injection vulnerabilities and ensure that parameterized queries and input validations are correctly implemented.
  • Automate Security Testing: Integrate static code analysis and dynamic application security testing (DAST) tools into the development pipeline to identify and remediate vulnerabilities.
  • Monitor Database Access Logs: Continuously monitor and audit database access logs for any signs of injection attempts or suspicious activities.

References:

  • OWASP SQL Injection Prevention Cheat Sheet

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers cause denial of service through resource exhaustion
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat occurs when attackers intentionally overload the Other Data Store by generating an excessive volume of requests or resource-intensive operations. By consuming disproportionate CPU, memory, disk I/O, or network bandwidth, the attackers can render the data store unresponsive or completely unavailable to legitimate users.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers using automated tools or botnets to flood the data store with high volumes of queries or operations.
  • Distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks that target the data store's endpoints.
  • Malicious insiders intentionally triggering resource-heavy processes to disrupt service.
  • Exploitation of inefficient query designs or misconfigurations that amplify resource consumption.

Impacts:

  • Complete or partial denial of service, leading to significant downtime.
  • Degradation in system performance and increased latency, affecting overall application responsiveness.
  • Financial losses and reputational damage due to prolonged service outages.
  • Potential cascading effects on dependent applications and services.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses a botnet to send a massive number of complex queries to the data store, causing resource exhaustion and making the service inaccessible to legitimate users.
  • A malicious insider repeatedly triggers resource-intensive operations during peak usage hours, overwhelming system capacity and resulting in a denial of service for critical business applications.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers exploit outdated vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat occurs when an Other Data Store runs on outdated software that contains known security vulnerabilities. Without regular updates and patches, these vulnerabilities remain exploitable, allowing attackers to compromise the system through unauthorized access, arbitrary code execution, or denial-of-service attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers using automated scanning tools to identify data stores running outdated versions.
  • Cybercriminals exploiting publicly disclosed vulnerabilities to gain control over the system.
  • Insider threats taking advantage of legacy systems with known security flaws.
  • Malware specifically designed to target unpatched components in the data store.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive or confidential data stored within the data store.
  • Execution of arbitrary code leading to potential system compromise and data manipulation.
  • Denial of service, causing disruption or complete unavailability of the data store.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within the network, potentially compromising additional systems.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker identifies an Other Data Store running an outdated version with a known vulnerability, then exploits it to gain administrative access and exfiltrate critical customer information.
  • A malware campaign targets unpatched data store installations, using a known exploit to inject malicious code, disrupt services, and propagate within the network.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers exfiltrate data due to insecure backup procedures
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat occurs when backup procedures for the Other Data Store are not implemented securely. Inadequate backup securitysuch as unencrypted backups or backups stored with weak access controlsenables attackers to access and exfiltrate sensitive data without directly compromising the live system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers scanning for misconfigured or publicly accessible backup repositories.
  • Insider threats abusing legitimate access to backup storage systems.
  • Malware or automated scripts targeting backup files with weak encryption or lax access controls.
  • Cybercriminals exploiting unsecured cloud storage where backup files are stored.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive or confidential data from backup files.
  • Financial and reputational damage due to data breaches and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
  • Potential for data manipulation or loss if backup integrity is compromised.
  • Extended recovery times and increased remediation costs in the event of a breach.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker identifies a misconfigured cloud storage bucket containing unencrypted backup files of the data store, accesses it remotely, and exfiltrates confidential customer records.
  • A malicious insider with access to backup systems downloads backup files stored without proper access controls and transfers them to an external location, allowing sensitive data to be leaked.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service

threat.name: Attackers intercept data due to unencrypted communications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat occurs when data transmitted between the Other Data Store and its clients or between the database nodes is not encrypted. Without proper encryption protocols in place, attackers can intercept, view, and potentially modify sensitive data as it travels across the network, compromising the confidentiality and integrity of the communication.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers using man-in-the-middle (MITM) techniques to intercept and capture unencrypted traffic.
  • Adversaries exploiting unsecured networks such as public Wi-Fi or untrusted private networks to eavesdrop on data transmissions.
  • Malware or malicious actors within the network that gain access to unencrypted data being transferred.
  • Insider threats with access to network infrastructure monitoring or capturing unencrypted data.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive information, such as personal data, financial details, or credentials.
  • Data manipulation or corruption if attackers modify the intercepted traffic before it reaches its destination.
  • Increased risk of further exploitation if session tokens, login credentials, or other sensitive data are captured.
  • Compliance violations and reputational damage from the exposure of confidential data.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker sets up a rogue Wi-Fi hotspot in a public area and intercepts unencrypted traffic between the client application and the Other Data Store, capturing login credentials and sensitive database queries.
  • A malicious insider with network access intercepts data exchanged between database nodes in an unencrypted form, allowing them to view and potentially alter critical operational data.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access due to weak authentication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat occurs when the Other Data Store is protected by weak or insufficient authentication mechanisms. Inadequate authenticationsuch as default credentials, simple or guessable passwords, or absence of multi-factor authenticationenables attackers to bypass security controls and gain unauthorized access to the system, potentially compromising sensitive data and system functionality.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers using automated brute-force or credential stuffing techniques.
  • Insider threats exploiting default or weak credentials to access the data store.
  • Adversaries leveraging social engineering tactics to obtain login information.
  • Automated scanning tools that detect systems with misconfigured or weak authentication settings.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive or confidential data stored in the data store.
  • Data manipulation, deletion, or corruption that compromises data integrity.
  • Potential lateral movement within the network, increasing the risk of broader system compromise.
  • Financial, regulatory, and reputational damage resulting from data breaches and security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker employs a brute-force tool to systematically guess weak or default credentials on a publicly exposed Other Data Store, eventually gaining full access and exfiltrating sensitive records.
  • A malicious insider takes advantage of a system configured with simple, easily guessable passwords, using their access to modify or delete critical data without triggering security alerts.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers exploit misconfigurations in data store settings
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat arises when an Other Data Store is deployed with improper or default configurations that do not follow security best practices. Misconfigurationssuch as unsecured default settings, overly permissive access controls, or unnecessary enabled featurescan provide attackers with opportunities to bypass security controls, access sensitive data, or disrupt database operations.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers using automated scanning tools to identify data stores with insecure configurations.
  • Cybercriminals exploiting default settings or misconfigured parameters to gain unauthorized access.
  • Insider threats abusing misconfigurations to elevate privileges or extract sensitive information.
  • Adversaries leveraging weak or incorrect settings (e.g., unrestricted network access) to compromise the data store.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to confidential data and administrative functions.
  • Data manipulation, corruption, or deletion, leading to compromised data integrity.
  • Service disruption or degraded performance due to resource misuse or exploitation.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within the network, potentially impacting other systems.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker discovers an Other Data Store that has not been hardened, with default credentials and open network access, allowing them to log in and exfiltrate sensitive data.
  • A malicious insider identifies misconfigured access controls in the data store settings, using the lax security to modify critical records or escalate privileges, resulting in data integrity issues and operational disruptions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Attackers exploit injection vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat arises when input validation and sanitization are inadequate in the Other Data Store, allowing attackers to inject malicious commands or code into data queries. Injection vulnerabilities enable adversaries to manipulate the query logic, potentially bypassing security controls, accessing unauthorized data, or causing unintended operations within the data store.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers using automated tools or manual techniques to identify injection points.
  • Cybercriminals exploiting vulnerable web forms or APIs that interact with the data store.
  • Insider threats manipulating query inputs to alter data or extract sensitive information.
  • Adversaries leveraging misconfigured or legacy code that does not enforce proper input validation.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to or modification of sensitive data stored in the data store.
  • Data corruption or deletion due to manipulated queries.
  • Bypass of authentication and authorization controls, leading to broader system compromise.
  • Potential cascading effects on application integrity, performance, and compliance with data protection regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker submits a crafted input through a vulnerable web form that injects malicious commands, enabling them to retrieve confidential user data from the Other Data Store.
  • A malicious insider exploits a poorly validated API endpoint to inject additional SQL commands, resulting in the deletion of critical records and disruption of business operations.

threat.name: Attackers tamper with data due to insecure file permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat occurs when the Other Data Store's database files are stored with overly permissive file system permissions. Insecure permissions allow unauthorized users or processes to modify, corrupt, or delete data, bypassing application-level security controls and undermining data integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • External attackers who gain access to the system through compromised credentials or vulnerabilities and exploit weak file permissions.
  • Insider threats abusing legitimate access to alter or delete sensitive data.
  • Malware or automated scripts scanning for systems with misconfigured file permissions to modify database files.
  • Physical access by unauthorized individuals who directly manipulate storage media.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized modification, deletion, or corruption of data, leading to loss of data integrity.
  • Potential exposure of sensitive or confidential information if file modifications are exploited.
  • Service disruption and potential downtime due to corrupted or lost data.
  • Regulatory and reputational damage resulting from compromised data security.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability to gain shell access to a server, then accesses a data store file with permissive permissions to modify transaction records, causing financial discrepancies.
  • A malicious insider takes advantage of weak file permissions to delete critical database files during off-hours, leading to prolonged downtime and data loss.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1222 - File and Directory Permissions Modification

weakness.name: CWE-1060
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1060: Excessive Number of Inefficient Server-Side Data Accesses The product performs too many data queries without using efficient data processing functionality such as stored procedures.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Automate dependency scanning and updating for security
countermeasure.desc:
Incorporate tools into the deployment pipeline that automatically scan for outdated or vulnerable dependencies and update them to the latest secure versions. Use dependency management tools that integrate with the pipeline to check for known vulnerabilities in third-party libraries or packages. Automate the update process to ensure that dependencies are always running the latest secure versions and reduce the risk of exposure to known security flaws.

References:

  • OWASP Dependency-Check

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity
SI-6 Security and Privacy Function Verification
SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1033 - Limit Software Installation
SI-6 Security and Privacy Function Verification

countermeasure.name: Implement RBAC to enforce strict access permissions for the deployment pipeline
countermeasure.desc:
Implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) to enforce strict access permissions and ensure that only authorized users can access the deployment pipeline. Define and assign roles based on the principle of least privilege, granting users and systems the minimum level of access necessary to perform their tasks. Regularly review and update role assignments to ensure that only appropriate personnel have access to sensitive pipeline operations, including private signature key management.

References:

  • Cloud IAM Best Practices

ID.AM-6: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for the entire workforce and third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) are established
ID.GV-2: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities are coordinated and aligned with internal roles and external partners
ID.SC-4: Suppliers and third-party partners are routinely assessed using audits, test results, or other forms of evaluations to confirm they are meeting their contractual obligations.

Responsibilities after termination or change of employment

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Log all pipeline actions for traceability and incident response
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all actions performed within the deployment pipeline are thoroughly logged to provide comprehensive traceability of activities involving private signature keys. These logs should capture events such as key access, modifications, deployments, and any security-related operations. Integrate logging with monitoring and alerting systems to facilitate real-time detection of potential incidents, enabling prompt response and investigation. Regularly audit the logs to ensure compliance with security policies and to identify unusual or unauthorized actions.

References:

  • CI/CD Pipeline Security Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Store artifacts in secure, encrypted locations with restricted access
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all deployment artifacts, including private signature keys, configuration files, and other sensitive data, are stored in secure, encrypted locations. Use encryption both at rest and in transit to protect these artifacts from unauthorized access. Implement strict access controls to ensure that only authorized personnel or systems have access to the artifacts, and enforce monitoring to detect any unauthorized attempts to access them.

References:

  • Best Practices for Securing Artifacts in CI/CD

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Use secrets management tools for secure sensitive information management
countermeasure.desc:
Implement tools such as Azure Key Vault or AWS Secrets Manager to securely store and manage sensitive information, including private signature keys, credentials, API keys, and other secrets. These tools provide centralized management, secure storage, and access control mechanisms, ensuring that sensitive information is protected from unauthorized access. Integrate these tools into your deployment pipeline to automatically fetch and use secrets in a secure manner during runtime.

References:

  • Azure Key Vault Documentation
